column3: What is the purpose of the Brokerage Relationship Disclosure Act?
column4: To provide customers with a greater understanding of real estate transactions and broker relationships

column4: refuse offers the agent knows will be unacceptable to the principal

column5: necessary to earn the promised compensation
column6: necessary to procure a customer
column7: comparable to that of other practitioners in the area
column9: The agent is hired to do a job, and is therefore expected to do it with diligence and reasonable competence.  Competence is generally defined as a "standard of practice" equal to the level of real estate marketing skills and knowledge of other practitioners in the area

column3: Agent Michael is showing his new listing to a buyer who informs him that he has just inherited five million dollars.  Michael is now bound by fiduciary duty to
column4: keep the information in confidence
column5: disclose the information to the buyer's agent
column6: disclose the information to the seller
column7: verify the buyer's statements before disclosing them to the client
column9: An agent has the duty to inform the client of all material facts, reports, and rumors that might affect the client's interests in the property transaction.  This includes: the agent's opinion of the property's condition; information about the buyer's motivations and financial qualifications; discussions between agent and buyer regarding the possibility of the agent's representing the buyer in another transaction

column3: Agent Gerry has executed an exclusive buyer broker agreement with the Andersons.  The agent subsequently places an offer with Melinda, the exclusive selling agent for the Lincolns, to buy their lakefront property. column4: the Andersons
column5: the Lincolns
column6: Gerry's broker
column7: Melinda's broker
column9: Since Gerry executed an agency agreement with the Andersons, they become the client and the Lincolns the customer, regardless of who pays the commission

column3: A subagent is the agent of
column4: the seller
column5: the buyer
column6: a broker who has an agency relationship with a client
column7: the client's and the customer's agents
column9: In a subagency, a broker or licensed sales associate works as the agent of a broker who is the agent of a client.  Subagents might include a cooperating licensed broker, that broker's licensed sales associates, and the listing broker's licensed sales associates, all of whom agree to work for the listing broker on behalf of the client

column3: Which of the following is a dual agency situation?
column4: Two agents share the exclusive right to represent the same client on all transactions
column5: One agent represents both sides in a transaction
column6: A selling agent from one brokerage works with a listing agent from another brokerage to complete a transaction
column7: One agent represents two sellers at the same time
column9: Dual agency means representing both principal parties to a transaction. The agent represents both buyer and seller or tenant and owner

column3: The duties of a transaction broker or facilitator include
column4: preserving the confidentiality of information received from either party
column5: helping the two parties achieve their respective objectives
column6: disclosing material facts that affect the value of the property to both parties
column7: choosing to obey the instructions of one party and informing the other party of the decision
column9: In the role of facilitator, the broker's only fiduciary duties and standards of conduct are those of accounting; skill, care, and diligence; honesty and fair dealing; and disclosure to both parties of all material facts in residential sale transactions affecting the property's value.  Some states do not allow for this form of relationship in a real estate transaction

column3: In which of the following contact situations would a seller's agent be expected to disclose his agency relationships?
column4: The agent is showing the client's property to a prospective buyer
column5: The agent tells an acquaintance at a party about the client's property
column6: The agent answers questions about the client's property for a telephone caller responding to a newspaper ad
column7: The agent is showing a potential buyer houses in a certain price range in the multiple listing book
column9: Agency disclosure must occur upon "substantive contact" between the listing agent and a customer.  Examples of substantive contact include: showing the prospect a property; eliciting confidential information from a prospect regarding needs, motivation, or financial qualification; and executing a contractual offer to sell or lease

column3: The essential foundation of the agency relationship consists of
column4: mutual respect, compensation, and confidentiality
column5: diligence, results, and compensation
column6: service, marketing, and respect
column7: good faith, trust and confidence
column9: The essence of the agency relationship is trust, confidence, and mutual good faith.  The principal trusts the agent to exercise the utmost skill and care in fulfilling the authorized activity, and to promote the principal's best interests.   The agent undertakes to strive in good faith to achieve the desired objective, and to fulfill the fiduciary duties

column3: Audrey wants to take a vacation.  To do so, she authorizes an agent to conduct the operations of one of her business enterprises.  The kind of agency she has established is
column4: limited
column5: general
column6: universal
column7: special
column9: In a general agency, the principal delegates to the agent ongoing tasks and duties within a particular business or enterprise.  Such delegation may include the authority to enter into contracts

column3: A property seller empowers an agent to market and sell a property on his behalf.  The kind of agency represented is
column4: general
column5: special
column6: universal
column7: no agency
column9: Under a special agency agreement, the principal delegates authority to conduct a specific activity, after which the agency relationship terminates.   In most cases, the special agent may not bind the principal to a contract. Real estate brokerage is commonly based on a special agency

column3: Implied agency arises when
column4: an agent accepts an oral listing
column5: a principal accepts an oral listing
column6: a party creates an agency relationship outside of an express agreement
column7: a principal agrees to all terms of a written listing agreement, whether express or implied
column9: An agency relationship can arise by implication, intentionally or unintentionally.  Implication means that the parties act as if there were an agreement.  For example, if an agent promises a buyer to do everything possible to find a property at the lowest possible price, and the buyer accepts the proposition, there may be an implied agency relationship even though there is no specific agreement

column3: An agency relationship may be involuntarily terminated for which of the following reasons?
column4: Condemnation of the property
column5: Mutual consent
column6: Full performance
column7: Renewal of the agent's license
column9: An agency relationship may terminate contrary to the wishes of the parties by reason of: death or incapacity of either party; abandonment by the agent; condemnation or destruction of the property; renunciation; breach; bankruptcy; or revocation of the agent's license

column3: A principal discloses that she would sell a property for $500,000.  During the listing period, the house is listed and marketed for $530,000.  No offers come in, and the listing expires.  Three weeks later, the agent confides to a customer that the seller would have sold for less than the listed price.  Which of the following is true?
column4: The agent has violated the duty of confidentiality
column5: The agent has fulfilled all fiduciary duties, since the listing has expired
column6: The agent is violating the duties owed this customer
column7: The agent has created a dual agency situation with the customer
column9: An agent may not disclose any information that would harm the client's interests or bargaining position, or anything else the client wishes to keep secret.  The confidentiality standard is one of the duties that extends beyond the termination of the listing: at no time in the future may the agent disclose confidential information

column3: A principal instructs an agent to market a property only to families on the west side of the university campus.  The agent refuses to comply.  In this case,
column4: the agent has violated fiduciary duty
column5: the agent has not violated fiduciary duty
column6: the agent is liable for breaching the listing terms
column7: the agent should obey the instruction to salvage the listing
column9: Since it is illegal to refuse to show buyers the property based on where the buyers live, the agent has not violated fiduciary duty.  The duty of obedience only applies to legal activities

column3: An owner's agent is showing a buyer a residential property for sale.  The buyer notices water stains on the foundation walls and floor, and informs the agent.  The appropriate course of action for the agent is to
column4: immediately contract to paint the ceiling
column5: immediately contract to repair the roof
column6: suggest the buyer make a lower-price offer
column7: inform the seller
column9: An agent has the duty to inform the client of all material facts, reports, and rumors that might affect the client's interests in the property transaction

column3: The meaning and salient characteristics of the agency relationship should be disclosed to the client
column4: prior to completing a listing agreement
column5: prior to or upon completion of an offer
column6: upon the initial contact with the person
column7: prior to showing properties
column9: An agent who intends to represent a seller or owner must disclose the import of the proposed agency relationship in writing before the listing agreement is executed

column3: When must a listing agent disclose his or her agency relationship to prospective tenants or buyers?
column4: Immediately prior to the initial contact
column5: Upon initial contact
column6: Whenever substantive communication is made beyond casual conversation
column7: Immediately following any offer executed by the customer
column9: A listing agent must disclose in writing to a buyer or tenant that the agent represents the owner in the transaction.  This disclosure must occur before or at the first "substantive contact" with the customer prospect.  In some states, buyer representatives must disclose the agency relationship to sellers or their agents upon initial contact

column3: A buyer agent or tenant representative should disclose his or her agency relationship to the owner's agent
column4: immediately prior to the initial contact
column5: upon initial contact
column6: immediately prior to substantive contact
column7: immediately following any offer executed by the landlord
column9: A buyer agent must disclose the agency relationship to the seller or seller's agent on first contact.  Substantive contact is assumed to occur immediately in this circumstance

column3: An agent is operating as a disclosed dual agent on a transaction.  In this case, the agent
column4: may not represent one party's interests to the detriment of the other
column5: must operate without a listing agreement
column6: must be obedient and loyal to both parties
column7: must require that the principals refrain from disclosing any material facts to him
column9: A dual agent's first duty is to disclose the agency relationship to both principal parties or to withdraw from one side of the duality.  After disclosing, the agent must obtain the written consent of both parties.  If  both parties accept the dual agency, the agent owes all the fiduciary duties to both parties except full disclosure, undivided loyalty, and exclusive representation of  one principal's interests

column3: An agent informs a buyer that a provision in a contract is very commonplace.  After explaining the clause, the agent assures the buyer that the clause does not mean anything significant.  If something goes wrong with the transaction, the agent could be liable for
column4: violating duties owed a customer
column5: misinterpreting the clause
column6: intentional misrepresentation
column7: practicing law without a license
column9: An agent should not act or speak outside the agent's area of expertise.  A customer may rely on anything an agent says, and the agent will be held accountable.  For example, an agent represents that a property will appreciate.  The buyer interprets this as expert investment advice and buys the property.  If the property does not appreciate, the buyer may hold the agent liable

column3: Which of the following is required of a brokerage office?
column4: Locked file cabinets
column5: At least three total rooms
column6: Entrance sign
column7: Separate conference room
column9: "Each active broker shall maintain a sign on or about the entrance of her or his principal office and each branch office" 475.22

column3: Which of the following statements is FALSE?
column4: All advertising must include the brokerage phone number and image of the broker
column5: Advertising must not be deceptive
column6: The broker's name must appear on advertising as it is registered with the FREC
column7: In online ads, the brokerage name must appear in close proximity to the contact information
column9: While the brokerage name is required, the phone number and picture of the broker are not

column3: Regarding escrow accounts, which of the following is true?
column4: Sales associates must deposit funds into the account the same day they are received
column5: A broker may designate a sales associate to be signatory on all accounts
column6: The brokers has a lien on all escrow deposits
column7: The broker has 30 days to correct any account errors
column9: "A broker shall be provided a reasonable amount of time to correct escrow errors if there is no shortage of funds and such errors pose no significant threat to economically harm the public. For purposes of this subsection, reasonable amount of time shall be defined as 30 days from the date the last reconciliation statement was performed or should have been performed." 61J2-14.010

column3: If escrow funds are held by a title company,
column4: the title company must provide a deposit receipt within 5 days of deposit being received
column5: the title company must provide written verification of receipt of a deposit directly to the seller if the seller is represented by a broker
column6: the licensee must name the title company on the sales contract
column7: the licensee must provide verification of deposit receipt within 10 days of deposit due date
column9: "When a deposit is placed or to be placed with a title company or an attorney, the licensee who prepared or presented the sales contract ('Licensee'), shall indicate on that contract the name, address, and telephone number of such title company or attorney. Within ten (10) business days after each deposit is due under the sales contract, the Licensee’s broker shall make written request to the title company or attorney to provide written verification of receipt of the deposit, unless the deposit is held by a title company or by an attorney nominated in writing by a seller or seller’s agent. Within ten (10) business days of the date the Licensee’s broker made the written request for verification of the deposit, the Licensee’s broker shall provide Seller’s broker with either a copy of the written verification, or, if no verification is received by Licensee’s broker, written notice that Licensee’s broker did not receive verification of the deposit. If Seller is not represented by a broker, then Licensee’s broker shall notify the Seller directly in the same manner indicated herein." 61J2-14

column3: Examples of antitrust violations would include which of the following?
column4: Blockbusting and adverse possession
column5: Redlining and police powers
column6: Point of beginning and market rebalancing
column7: Collusion, price fixing and market allocation
column9: Antitrust laws primarily focus on promoting fair trade and fair trade practices.  Among the most common antitrust violations are collusion, price fixing and market allocation.  In every case a market competitor is guilty of attempting to acquire an unfair competitive advantage over another competitor.

column3: The Florida Antitrust Act of 1980 was enacted
column4: to complement the federal antitrust laws
column5: to replace federal antitrust regulations in Florida
column6: because federal antitrust laws are outdated
column7: because there are no federal antitrust laws
column9: "The Legislature declares it to be the purpose of this act to complement the body of federal law prohibiting restraints of trade or commerce in order to foster effective competition." 542.16

column3: A broker has not violated Florida antitrust laws if he/she
column4: meets with another brokerage to compare listed properties
column5: meets with another brokerage to set the percentage amount of commission splits offered in the market
column6: gets other brokers to boycott a competitor for discounting rates
column7: agrees with another brokers to set commission rates
column9: Comparing listed properties does not constitute any form of trade restraints, conspiracy, monopolization, etc

column3: A sales associate may collect a commission directly from the seller only when

column5: his/her employer consents
column6: he/she has sued the seller
column7: he/she collects the commission in his/her own name
column9: Sales associates may only collect commissions in the name of the employer and with the consent of the employer and may only perform real estate services on behalf of employer. Sales associates may not sue the principal to obtain the commission

column3: If Sales Associate Bob is working with a listing agreement that provides for a 7% commission, how much would Bob actually receive if the selling price of the property is $200,000 and the buyer's broker is to receive half of the overall commission and Bob is to receive half of his broker employer's cut?
column9: 7% of $200,000=$14,000. Half to the buyer's broker=$7,000. The other half goes to Bob's broker who gives Bob half to = $3,500

column3: What is a kickback?
column4: The action taken when a new employer kicks the sales associate back to a previous employer
column5: The action taken when a broker applicant fails the license examination and must retake it
column6: Monies paid to the FREC when renewing a license
column7: Monies paid to a broker for using a particular service provider during a real estate transaction
column9: The definition of kickback is payment of something of value to a recipient as compensation or reward for providing favorable treatment to another party. In real estate, most kickbacks involve mortgage providers, inspectors, or home improvement providers

column3: If a broker receives a kickback, what must he or she do?
column4: Disclose it to all involved parties
column5: Deposit the funds into an escrow account
column6: Notify his or her employer
column7: Never use the particular service provider again
column9: "Any real estate licensee who receives, or makes any arrangement or agreement to receive, directly or indirectly, any kickback or rebate… shall have fully advised the principal if any and all affected parties in the transaction(s), which the licensee is handling, of all facts pertaining to the arrangement of kickbacks or rebates. " 61J2-10.028

column3: Which of the following statements is true regarding a sales associate's changing employers?
column4: The former employer must notify the FREC within 30 days of the associate's termination
column5: Unless the former employer's license has been suspended, the associate's license remains in force during the change of employer

column7: The associate may not remove any records from the former employer's office
column9: "A license shall cease to be in force whenever a broker changes her or his business address, a real estate school operating under a permit issued pursuant to s. 475.451 changes its business address, or a sales associate working for a broker or an instructor working for a real estate school changes employer. column3: Which of the following statements is false when a business entity wishes to register as a brokerage?
column4: The entity must have at least one active broker or sales associate as an officer, director, member, manager, or partner
column5: The entity must submit an application for brokerage and pay a fee
column6: A broker-associate may be an officer, director, member, manager, or partner of the entity only if he/she has been upgraded to an active broker
column7: A sales associate may not be an officer, director, member, manager, or partner of the entity

column4: Sole proprietorship
column5: Corporate sole
column6: General partnership

column7: be used by a sales associate

column3: Under Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices, the penalty for willful unfair or fraudulent advertising is
column4: civil penalty of not more than $10,000

column6: reprimand by FREC

column9: An ordinary lease is a common example of the transfer of a portion of one's bundle of rights. The owner relinquishes the right to possess portions of the surface, perhaps a building, in return for rent.  The tenant enjoys the rights to possess and use the building over the term of the lease, after which these rights revert to the landlord.  During the lease term, the tenant has no rights to the property's subsurface or airspace other than what the building occupies.  Further, the tenant does not enjoy any of the other rights in the bundle of rights: he or she cannot encumber the property or transfer it.  To a limited degree, the tenant may exclude persons other than the legal owner from the property

Since the advent of aviation, property owners' air rights have been curtailed to allow aircraft to fly over one's property provided the overflights do not interfere with the owner's use and enjoyment of the property.  The issue of violation of air rights for the benefit of air transportation is an ongoing battle between aircraft owners, airlines, airports, and nearby property owners

Owners of properties abutting a navigable, non-moving body of water enjoy the littoral right of use, but do not own the water nor the land beneath the water.  The legal premise underlying the definition of littoral rights is that a lake or sea is a navigable body of water, therefore, public property owned by the state.  By contrast, a body of water entirely contained within the boundaries of an owner's property is not navigable.  In such a case, the owner would own the water as well as unrestricted rights of usage

In such a case, the owner's property extends t the water's edge as opposed to the midpoint of the waterway

column9: A personal property item that has been converted to real property by attachment to real estate is called a fixture.  Typical examples are chandeliers, toilets, water pumps, septic tanks, and window shutters. The owner of real property inherently owns all fixtures belonging to the real property.  When the owner sells the real property, the buyer acquires rights to all fixtures

column3: An item may be considered personal property as opposed to real property provided that
column4: the owner intended to remove it after a period of time
column5: it can be removed without altering the appearance of the structure
column6: it is unnecessary to the physical integrity of the structure
column7: the owner installed it at some time after acquiring the real property
column9: One's original intention can override the test of movability in determining whether an item is a fixture or not.  If someone attached an item to real property, yet intended to remove it after a period of time, the article may be deemed personal property.  If a person intended an article to be a fixture, even though the item is easily removable, the article may be deemed a fixture.  For example, an apartment renter installs an alarm system, fully intending to remove the system upon lease expiration.  Here, the alarm system would be considered personal property

column3: Two people own a house, each having an undivided equal interest.  Which of the following best describes what each party owns?
column4: Fifty percent of the physical house and the land it rests on
column5: One hundred percent of the home and the land
column6: Fifty percent of the estate consisting of the indivisible whole of the real property
column7: Each owns one hundred percent of the estate represented by the real property and fifty percent of the physical house and the land it rests on
column9: An undivided interest is an owner's fractional interest in an entire (undivided) estate, but not in a physical portion of the real property itself. An owner who has an undivided equal interest with another cannot exercise exclusive rights over a portion of the real estate, which is an indivisible whole

column3: A real property interest that includes the right to possess is considered
column4: an estate in land
column5: a leasehold estate
column6: a fee simple estate
column7: the bundle of rights
column9: Interests are principally distinguished by whether they include possession.  If the interest-holder enjoys the right of possession, the party is considered to have an estate in land, or, familiarly an estate.  Freehold and leasehold estates in land are further distinguished by whether the duration of the owner's rights can be determined

column3: The right to control land usage by zoning and  eminent domain is an example of
column4: a public interest
column5: a police interest
column6: an encumbrance
column7: an estate in law
column9: Public entities may own or lease real estate, in which case they enjoy an estate in land.  However, government entities also have non-possessory interests in real estate which act to control land use for the public good within the entity's jurisdiction.  The prime example of public interest is police power, or the right of the local or county government to zone.  Another example of public interest is the right to acquire ownership through the power of eminent domain

column3: If the duration of an owner's rights in an estate is not determinable, the owner has
column4: a tenancy at sufferance
column5: a leased fee simple estate
column6: a freehold estate
column7: a leasehold estate
column9: In a freehold estate, the duration of the owner's rights cannot be determined: the rights may endure for a lifetime, for less than a lifetime, or for generations beyond the owner's lifetime.  By contrast, leasehold estates have expirations

column3: The distinguishing feature of a leasehold estate is
column4: ownership of an interest by a tenant
column5: temporary ownership of the full bundle of rights in a property
column6: unlimited ownership of one right in the bundle of rights in a property
column7: that the estate is limited by a lease term
column9: A leasehold estate is distinguished by its specific duration, as represented by the lease term.  Further, leasehold tenants only enjoy limited property rights: use; temporary possession, and limited exclusion

column3: Paul gives Dennis a life estate and designates Lucy as the remainderman.  Dennis sells the property to Allen.  When Dennis dies who owns the property as a fee simple estate?
column4: The state of Florida
column5: Dennis
column6: Paul
column7: Lucy
column9: Once Dennis dies, the estate goes to Lucy.  The state of Florida would not be involved after Dennis’s death as it would be clear the property is to go to Lucy.

column3: Ned grants his sister Alice an estate for as long as she lives.  Her descendants, however,  cannot inherit the estate. What kind of estate is it?
column4: An estate pur autre vie
column5: An estate for years
column6: An ordinary life estate
column7: A legal life estate
column9: A life estate is limited in duration to the life of the owner or other named person.  Upon the death of the owner (ordinary life estate) or other named individual (pur autre vie life estate), the estate passes to the original owner (a reversionary interest) or another named party (a remainder interest).  Thus with the life estate, the owner enjoys full ownership rights during the estate period, and holders of the future interest own either a reversionary or a remainder interest

column3: Homestead estates are examples of
column4: a conventional life estate
column5: a legal life estate
column6: an estate created by an owner's agreement
column7: a fee simple absolute
column9: Homestead, dower, and curtesy are legal life estates.  A legal life estate is created by state law as opposed to being created by a property owner's agreement.  The focus of a legal life estate is defining and protecting the property rights of surviving family members upon the death of the husband or wife

column3: Louis owned a boat and a house before marrying Barbara.  While she was single, Barbara owned a new car.  The two got married and bought a second home.  As a wedding present, Barbara’s father bought Louis a motorcycle.  Under the law of community property, what property can Louis sell without his wife’s consent or signature?
column4: The boat and house
column5: The boat, house, and motorcycle
column6: The second home and the motorcycle
column7: The boat and motorcycle
column9: Separate property consists of: property owned by either spouse at the time of the marriage; property acquired by either spouse through inheritance or gift during the marriage; property acquired with separate-property funds; and income from separate property.  Community property consists of all other property earned or acquired by either party during the marriage. A spouse owns separate property free and clear of claims by the other spouse.  He or she can transfer it without the other spouse's signature.  Upon the death of the separate property owner, the property passes to heirs by will or laws of descent.  Community property cannot be transferred or encumbered without the signatures of both spouses.  Upon the death of either spouse, half of the deceased's community property passes to the surviving spouse, and the other half passes to the decedent's heirs

column3: Katelyn rents an apartment for one year.  What rights has she acquired under the leasehold?
column4: The right to exclude everyone from the premises
column5: The right to encumber the fee interest
column6: The right to sell the premises
column7: The right to possess and use the premises
column9: Leasehold tenants are entitled to possess and use the leased premises during the lease term in the manner prescribed in the lease.  They also have restricted rights to exclusion

column3: An estate from period-to-period will continue as long as
column4: the tenant makes, and landlord accepts, regular rent payments
column5: the term specified in the lease
column6: the period is less than a year
column7: the landlord has not sold the property
column9: In an estate from period-to-period, also called a periodic tenancy, the tenancy period automatically renews as long as the tenant pays rent in a timely manner and the landlord accepts it.  At the end of a tenancy period, if the landlord accepts another regular payment of rent, the leasehold is considered to be renewed for another period.  A conveyance of leased property does not cancel a leasehold interest

column3: An estate at will
column4: cannot be terminated
column5: is terminated only if so stated in the lessee's last will and testament
column6: terminates on the death of lessor or lessee
column7: terminates on the date specified in the lease agreement
column9: The estate at will, also called a tenancy at will, has no definite expiration date and hence no "renewal" cycle.  The landlord and tenant agree that the tenancy will have no specified termination date, provided rent is paid on time and other lease conditions are met.  For example, a son leases a house to his father and mother "forever," or until they want to move.  The estate at will is terminated by proper notice, or by the death of either party

column3: A tenant continues to occupy an apartment after lease expiration without the consent of the landlord.  This type of estate is called
column4: an estate at sufferance
column5: a holdover estate
column6: a canceled leasehold
column7: a hostile leasehold
column9: In an estate at sufferance, a tenant occupies the premises without consent of the landlord or other legal agreement with the landlord.  Usually such an estate involves a tenant who fails to vacate at the expiration of the lease, continuing occupancy without any right to do so. For example, a tenant violates the provisions of a lease and is evicted.  The tenant protests and refuses to leave despite the eviction order

column3: A tenant without a lease has been sending the landlord monthly rent checks, and the landlord continues to accept the payments.  What kind of leasehold estate exists?
column4: Estate for years
column5: Estate from period to period
column6: Estate at will
column7: Estate at sufferance
column9: In an estate from period-to-period, also called a periodic tenancy, the tenancy period automatically renews for an indefinite period of time, subject to timely payment of rent.  At the end of a tenancy period, if the landlord accepts another regular payment of rent, the leasehold is considered to be renewed for another period

column3: A fee or life estate is held by an individual.  This form of estate is referred to as a(an)
column4: tenancy in severalty
column5: tenancy by the entireties
column6: absolute fee simple
column7: legal fee simple
column9: If a single party owns the fee or life estate, the ownership is a tenancy in severalty.  Synonyms are sole ownership, ownership in severalty, and estate in severalty

column3: Six people have identical rights in a property and enjoy an indivisible interest.   However any of the owners may sell or transfer his/her interest without consent of the others.  This form of ownership is a
column4: joint tenancy
column5: homestead ownership
column6: tenancy in common
column7: estate in severalty
column9: The tenancy in common, also known as the estate in common, is the most common form of co-ownership when the owners are not married (though tenants in common can be married).  The defining characteristics are: two or more owners; identical rights; interests individually owned; electable ownership shares; no survivorship; and no unity of time.  With "identical rights", co-tenants share an indivisible interest in the estate, i.e., all have equal rights to possess and use the property subject to the rights of the other co-tenants

column3: The "four unities" required to create a joint tenancy include which of the following conditions?
column4: Parties must acquire respective interests at the same time
column5: Parties must be residents of the same state at the time of acquiring the interest
column6: Parties must be family members
column7: Parties must have joint financial responsibility
column9: To create a joint tenancy, all owners must acquire the property at the same time, use the same deed, acquire equal interests, and share in equal rights of possession.  These are referred to as the four unities

column3: Unlike tenants in common, joint tenants
column4: own distinct portions of the physical property
column5: cannot will their interest to a party outside the tenancy
column6: may own unequal shares of the property
column7: cannot encumber their interest to outside parties
column9: The survivorship feature of joint tenancy presents an advantage to tenancy in common, in that interests pass without probate proceedings.  On the other hand, joint tenants relinquish any ability to will their interest to parties outside of the tenancy

column3: Which of the following life estates is created by operation of  law rather than by the owner?
column4: Conventional life estate
column5: Ordinary life estate
column6: Legal life estate
column7: Community property life estate
column9: A legal life estate is created by state law as opposed to being created by a property owner's agreement.  The focus of a legal life estate is defining and protecting the property rights of surviving family members upon the death of the husband or wife

column3: Which of the following is true of a homestead?
column4: A homestead interest cannot be conveyed by one spouse
column5: A homestead interest cannot be passed to the children of the head of household
column6: A homestead interest is a form of conventional life estate
column7: A homestead is a primary or secondary residence occupied by a family
column9: A homestead is one's principal residence.  Homestead laws protect family members against losing their homes to general creditors attempting to collect on debts. Homestead laws generally provide that: the homestead interest cannot be conveyed by one spouse; both spouses must sign the deed conveying homestead property

column3: A tenant in common can
column4: sell or transfer his interest without the consent of the other tenants in common
column5: use his or her interest in the estate to encumber the entire estate
column6: sell, encumber or transfer his or her interest only to the other tenants in common
column7: sell, encumber or transfer his or her interest only with the consent of all the other tenants in common
column9: All tenants in common have distinct and separable ownership of their respective interests.  Co-tenants may sell, encumber, or transfer their interests without obstruction or consent from the other owners.   A co-tenant may not, however, encumber the entire property

column3: Which of the following would be considered community property?
column4: Property acquired before marriage
column5: A motorcycle bought after the marriage with separate property funds
column6: Income derived from community property
column7: A mother’s heirloom wedding ring gifted to the wife after her wedding
column9: If an income-producing property has been defined as community property, the revenue accruing from the investment is likewise community property

column3: When real property is held in a land trust, who controls the property?
column4: The trustor
column5: The trustee
column6: The beneficiary
column7: The mortgagee
column9: A land trust allows the trustor to convey the fee estate to the trustee and to name himself or herself the beneficiary.  The land trust applies only to real property, not to personal property.  The agreement, or deed in trust, grants the beneficiary the rights to possess and use the property, and to exercise control over the actions of the trustee

column3: In a separate property state, John marries Patricia.  Prior to the marriage John owned an SUV.  During the marriage, John bought a Buick, John and Patricia bought a second property with money earned from Patricia's job, and each individual received a motorcycle from Patricia's uncle as a gift.  What property will be split during the divorce?
column4: The SUV, the Buick, and the second property
column5: The SUV, the Buick, the second property, and the motorcycles
column6: The Buick and the second property
column7: The Buick, the second property, and the motorcycles
column9: Separate property belongs to one spouse. Separate property is that property which is acquired prior to the marriage, by gift or inheritance during the marriage, property acquired by separate-property funds, or income from separate property.

column3: Which of the following is true of a cooperative?
column4: A cooperative may hold an owner liable for the unpaid operating expenses of other tenants
column5: The owners have a fee simple interest in the airspace of their respective apartments
column6: Owners may sublease their apartments even if they sell their stock in the cooperative
column7: The proprietary lease is guaranteed to have a fixed rate of rent over the life of the lease term
column9: Since the corporation owns an undivided interest in the cooperative property, debts and financial obligations apply to the property as a whole, not to individual units as in a condominium

column3: Which of the following is true of a tenancy in common?
column4: The co-owners must be related
column5: The owners enjoy an indivisible interest
column6: The tenants must acquire their interests at the same time
column7: The tenants must pay equal amounts for their interest in the estate
column9: The tenancy in common, also known as the estate in common, is the most common form of co-ownership when the owners are not married (though tenants in common can be married).  The defining characteristics are: two or more owners; identical rights; interests individually owned; electable ownership shares; no survivorship; and no unity of time.  With "identical rights," co-tenants share an indivisible interest in the estate, i.e., all have equal rights to possess and use the property subject to the rights of the other co-tenants

column3: Carissa and Robert acquire a condominium as tenants in common.  In this circumstance, Carissa can
column4: sell her interest to a third party without the consent of Robert
column5: use her interest in the estate to mortgage the entire estate
column6: sell her interest only to Robert
column7: sell encumber or transfer her interest only with the consent of Robert
column9: All tenants in common have distinct and separable ownership of their respective interests.  Co-tenants may sell, encumber, or transfer their interests without obstruction or consent from the other owners.   A co-tenant may not, however, encumber the entire property

column3: When a tenant in common dies, what happens to the tenant's interest in the estate?
column4: It is divided equally among the surviving tenants in common
column5: The surviving tenants must buy the interest from the deceased tenant's heirs or sell their interests to the heirs
column6: It becomes a joint tenancy
column7: It passes by probate to the deceased tenant's heirs
column9: A deceased co-tenant's estate passes by probate to the decedent's heirs and devisees rather than to the other tenants in common.  Any number of heirs can share in the ownership of the willed tenancy

column3: Which of the following is true of a joint tenancy?
column4: The tenants can determine the size of the share owned by each tenant
column5: The size of the tenant's shares is determined by the amount of equity each has invested in the property
column6: The tenants have an equal and indivisible ownership interest
column7: There can be no more than two co-owners, and each has a fifty percent interest
column9: In a joint tenancy, two or more persons collectively own a property as if they were a single person.  Rights and interests are indivisible and equal: each has a shared interest in the whole property which cannot be divided up.  Joint tenants may only convey their interests to outside parties as tenant-in-common interests.  One can not convey a joint tenant interest

column3: In contrast to a tenancy in common, in a joint tenancy
column4: there is a single title to the property
column5: there are as many titles to the property as there are co-owners
column6: title is held by a trustee
column7: co-owners who are married hold separate titles
column9: Whereas tenants in common hold separate title to their individual interests, joint tenants together hold a single title to the property.  This is referred to as unity of ownership

column3: If a joint tenant sells his or her interest to an outside party,
column4: the new owner becomes a tenant in common with the other owners, who continue to hold a joint tenancy with each other and a tenancy in common with the new owner
column5: the joint tenancy continues with the new owner as the third joint tenant
column6: the joint tenancy terminates and all owners become tenants in common
column7: the joint tenancy terminates and the owners must create a new joint tenancy to include the new owner
column9: A joint tenant may transfer his or her interest in the property to an outside party, but only as a tenancy in common interest.  Whoever acquires the interest co-owns the property as a tenant in common with the other joint tenants.  The remaining joint tenants continue to own an undivided interest in the property, less the new co-tenant's share

column3: When a joint tenant dies, what happens to the tenant's interest in the estate?
column4: It passes to the decedent's heirs, who become joint tenants
column5: It passes as a tenancy in common to the decedent's heirs
column6: The joint tenancy terminates and becomes a tenancy in common with the decedent's heirs and the surviving tenants as co-owners
column7: It passes to the surviving joint tenants
column9: In most states, joint tenants enjoy rights of survivorship: if a joint tenant dies, all interests and rights pass to the surviving joint tenants free from any claims of creditors or heirs. When only one joint tenant survives, the survivor's interest becomes an estate in severalty, and the joint tenancy is terminated

column3: Under what conditions can two individuals own a property as tenants by the entireties?
column4: If they so elect at the time of acquiring title
column5: If they are blood relatives
column6: If they are married
column7: If they incorporate
column9: Tenancy by the entireties is a form of ownership reserved exclusively for husband and wife.   It features survivorship, equal interests, and limited exposure to foreclosure

column3: When an estate is held in a trust, which party holds legal title?
column4: The beneficiary
column5: The trustor
column6: The trustee
column7: The grantor
column9: In an estate in trust, a fee owner-- the grantor or trustor-- transfers legal title to a fiduciary-- the trustee-- who holds and manages the estate for the benefit of another party, the beneficiary.   The trust may be created by a deed, will, or trust agreement

column3: Tanya buys a 4-bedroom condominium.  As the new owner, she has the right to
column4: sell or mortgage the unit without impediment from individual owners of neighboring units
column5: sell the interest in the physical unit separately from the interest in the common elements
column6: prevent non-owners from using the unit owner's portion of the common elements
column7: exclusively possess and use those portions of the common areas structurally or functionally necessary for the operation of the unit
column9: Condominium units can be individually sold, mortgaged, or otherwise encumbered without interference from other unit owners.  An owner may not sell interests in the apartment separately from the interest in the common elements.  Unit owners exclusively possess their apartment space, but must share common areas with other owners

column3: A condominium owner's share of maintenance and operations expenses are based on
column4: the unit's pro rata share of floor space
column5: the unit's pro rata share of the property value as defined in the declaration
column6: the number of shares the owner purchased in the condominium association
column7: the assessed value of the condominium unit
column9: The unit's pro rata share of the property's ownership as defined in the declaration determines the amount of a unit owner's assessment.  For example, if a unit represents a 2% share of the property value, that unit owner's assessment will be 2% of the property's common area expenses

column3: By contrast to a condominium, the owner of a cooperative owns
column4: shares in a corporation or association and a proprietary lease in a physical unit
column5: a fee simple interest in a physical unit plus a tenancy in common in common elements
column6: a tenancy in common in a physical unit and the common areas
column7: a ground lease in the physical unit's pro rata share of land and a proprietary lease in the unit
column9: In a cooperative, or co-op, one owns shares in a non-profit corporation or cooperative association, which in turn acquires and owns an apartment building as its principal asset.  Along with this stock, the shareholder acquires a proprietary lease to occupy one of the apartment units

column3: In a cooperative, real property is owned only by
column4: the individual unit owners
column5: the individual unit owners and the cooperative association
column6: the cooperative developer
column7: the corporate entity of the cooperative association
column9: The corporate entity of the cooperative association is the only party in the cooperative with a real property interest.  The association's interest is an undivided interest in the entire property.  There is no ownership interest in individual units, as with a condominium

column3: In a time-share freehold, owners acquire
column4: undivided interests in the property as tenants in common
column5: a renewable periodic tenancy from for a portion of a year
column6: a pro rata share of a leased fee
column7: a tenancy in severalty for a portion of a year
column9: In a freehold time-share, or interval ownership estate, tenants in common own undivided interests in the property.  Expense prorations and rules governing interval usage are established by separate agreement when the estate is acquired

column3: Which of the following types of leasehold estate lacks a specific term?
column4: Estate for years
column5: Estate from period-to-period
column6: Estate at will
column7: Estate by the entireties
column9: Three of the four principal types of leasehold estate are: the estate for years, which has a specific lease term; the estate from period-to-period, where the lease term of a specific period automatically renews; and the estate at will, which has no specified lease term.  The fourth principal type, the estate at sufferance, is a tenancy without consent that therefore also has no specific term

column3: Which of the following describes an encumbrance?
column4: A third party’s right encroach upon a property without the permission of the property owner
column5: A third party’s right to claim the sale proceeds of a property that has been mortgaged as collateral for a loan
column6: A third party’s interest in a real property that limits the interests of the freehold property owner
column7: Another's right to acquire a freehold interest in a property against the property owner's wishes
column9: An encumbrance is an interest in and right to real property that limits the legal owner's freehold interest.  In effect, an encumbrance is another's right to use or take possession of a legal owner's property, or to prevent the legal owner from enjoying the full bundle of rights in the estate

column3: Which of the following is true of easements in general?
column4: They involve the property that contains the easement and a non-owning party
column5: They apply to a whole property, not to any specific portion of the property
column6: They only involve the legal owner of the property
column7: They may require a specific use, but cannot prohibit one
column9: an interest in real property that gives the holder the right to use portions of the legal owner's real property in a defined way.  One cannot own an easement over one's own property. Easement rights may apply to a property's surface, subsurface, or airspace, but the affected area must be defined.  An easement may be affirmative, allowing a use, such as a right-of-way, or negative,  prohibiting a use, such as an airspace easement that prohibits one property owner from obstructing another's ocean view

column3: Mr. King wants to offer 100 acres of his property for sale.  Since the property is landlocked, he will have to put in a driveway to the road that will run across his remaining property.  What kind of easement will he have to grant?
column4: An easement in gross
column5: A commercial easement
column6: A personal easement
column7: An easement appurtenant
column9: An easement appurtenant gives a property owner a right of usage to portions of an adjoining property owned by another party.  The property enjoying the usage right is called the dominant tenement, or dominant estate.  The property containing the physical easement itself is the servient tenement, since it must serve the easement use

column3: If property Alpha has a court-ordered easement across property Beta in order for Alpha to have access to a public road, the easement is a(n)
column4: easement by prescription
column5: personal easement
column6: easement by necessity
column7: easement in gross
column9: An easement by necessity is an easement appurtenant granted by a court of law to a property owner because of a circumstance of necessity, most commonly the need for access to a property. Since property cannot be legally landlocked, or without legal access to a public thoroughfare, a court will grant an owner of a landlocked property an easement by necessity over an adjoining property that has access to a thoroughfare

column3: An encroachment is
column4: an easement that has not been recorded on the title of the burdened property
column5: an unauthorized physical intrusion of one property into another
column6: a right granted by a property owner to the owner of an adjoining property to build a structure that protrudes across the property boundary
column7: a structure that does not comply with a zoning ordinance
column9: An encroachment is the unauthorized, physical intrusion of one owner's real property into that of another.   Examples of encroachments are: a tree limb extending into the neighbor's property, violating his or her airspace; a driveway extending beyond the lot line onto the neighbor's land; and a fence built beyond the property line

column3: A court might grant an easement by prescription if
column4: a town needs to dig a trench across an owner's property to install a sewer line to a  neighboring property, and the owner refuses permission
column5: a property owner sells the front half of a lot and wants to continue using the driveway to access the rear of the lot
column6: a trespasser has been using an owner's property for a certain period with the owner's knowledge but without permission
column7: a property owner wants to prevent the owner of an adjoining property from building a an improvement that blocks her view
column9: If someone uses another's property as an easement without permission for a statutory period of time and under certain conditions, a court order may give the user the easement right by prescription, regardless of the owner's desires.  For a prescriptive easement order to be granted, the following circumstances must be true: the use has been occurring without permission or license; the owner knows or is presumed to have known of the use; and the use has been generally uninterrupted over the statutory prescriptive period

column3: The purpose of a deed restriction is to enable an owner to specify
column4: the form of ownership in which a property may be held
column5: how long a property must be owned before it can be legally transferred
column6: what groups of people are legally excluded from future ownership of a property
column7: how a property may be used and what improvements may be built on it
column9: A deed restriction is a limitation imposed on a buyer's use of a property by stipulation in the deed of conveyance or recorded subdivision plat. A deed restriction may apply to a single property or to an entire subdivision.  A developer may place restrictions on all properties within a recorded subdivision plat.  Subsequent re-sales of properties within the subdivision are thereby subject to the plat's covenants and conditions

column3: Melinda purchases a house and finances it.  The lender in turn places a lien on Melinda’s title.  The lien in this mortgage transaction is
column4: evidence of debt incurred by a property owner
column5: a promissory note granted by a property owner as security for a debt
column6: the creditor's claim against the property as collateral security for the loan
column7: the document required to clear clouded title
column9: A lien is a creditor's claim against personal or real property as security for a debt of the property owner.  If the owner defaults, the lien gives the creditor the right to force the sale of the property to satisfy the debt.  For example, a homeowner borrows $5,000 to pay for a new roof.  The lender funds the loan in exchange for the borrower's promissory note to repay the loan.  At the same time, the lender places a lien on the property for $5,000 as security for the debt.  If the borrower defaults, the lien allows the lender to force the sale of the house to satisfy the debt

column3: In a lien-theory state, what kind of interest does a mortgage lender have in the liened property?
column4: A possessory interest
column5: A tenancy-by-mortgagee interest
column6: A legal interest in a pro rata share of the property
column7: An equitable interest
column9: A lienor generally has an equitable interest in the property, but not legal ownership.  The exception is a mortgage lien on a property in a title-theory state.  In these states, the mortgage transaction conveys legal title to the lender, who holds it until the mortgage obligations are satisfied.  During the mortgage loan period, the borrower has equitable title to the property

column3: How is a lien terminated?
column4: Payment of the debt that is the subject of the lien and recording of the satisfaction
column5: Transfer of the property that has the lien
column6: Recording of another lien that is superior
column7: Death of the lienor or lienee
column9: A lien terminates on payment of the debt and recording of documents.  Payment of the debt and recording of the appropriate satisfaction documents ordinarily terminate a lien.  If a default occurs, a suit for judgment or foreclosure enforces the lien.  These actions force the sale of the property

column3: A judge rules in favor of the creditor in a court proceeding and places a judgment lien against all the debtor's assets, including his real property.  This is an example of a(n)
column4: voluntary junior lien
column5: involuntary superior lien
column6: involuntary specific lien
column7: involuntary general lien
column9: A general lien is one placed against any and all real and personal property owned by a particular debtor.  An example is an inheritance tax lien placed against all property owned by the heir.  A specific lien attaches to a single item of real or personal property and does not affect other property owned by the debtor. In addition, judgment liens are junior, involuntary liens

column3: A real estate tax lien, a federal income tax lien, a judgment lien, and a mortgage lien are recorded against a property. Which lien will be paid first when the property is sold?
column4: Real estate tax lien
column5: Federal income tax lien
column6: Judgment lien
column7: Mortgage lien
column9: The category of superior, or senior, liens ranks above the category of inferior, or junior, liens, meaning that superior liens receive first payment from the proceeds of a foreclosure.   The superior category includes liens for real estate tax, special assessments, and inheritance tax.  Other liens, including income tax liens, mortgage liens and judgment liens, are inferior

column3: A lien holder can change the lien priority of a junior lien by agreeing to
column4: change the date of recording
column5: lower the amount of the claim
column6: cancel the lien
column7: subordinate the lien
column9: A lienor can change the priority of a junior lien by voluntarily agreeing to subordinate, or lower, the lien's position in the hierarchy.   This change is often necessary when working with a mortgage lender who will not originate a mortgage loan unless it is senior to all other junior liens on the property.  The lender may require the borrower to obtain agreements from other lien holders to subordinate their liens to the new mortgage

column3: Which of the following accurately describes the act of foreclosure?
column4: A court-ordered acceleration of loan payments
column5: The final step in a bankruptcy filing
column6: A proceeding to enforce a lien by forcing the sale or transfer of a secured property
column7: A proceeding to take equitable title to a property that was liened as security for a mortgage loan
column9: All liens can be enforced by the sale or other transfer of title of the secured property, whether by court action, operation of law, or through powers granted in the original loan agreement.  The enforcement proceedings are referred to as foreclosure.  Note that lienors already possess equitable title, so they do not need to undertake a legal proceeding to establish this

column3: A property is secured by a mortgage that does not contain a "power of sale" clause.  To foreclose, the lien holder will have to
column4: file a deficiency suit
column5: file a foreclosure suit
column6: file a suit to quiet title
column7: obtain a quit claim deed
column9: Judicial foreclosure occurs in states that use a two-party mortgage document (borrower and lender) that does not contain a "power of sale" provision.  Lacking this provision, a lender must file a foreclosure suit and undertake a court proceeding to enforce the lien

column3: A homeowner defaults on his mortgage loan.  In the subsequent foreclosure action, the lender takes title to the liened property directly instead of initiating a court-ordered public sale.  This is an example of
column4: strict foreclosure
column5: judicial foreclosure
column6: non-judicial foreclosure
column7: deed in lieu of foreclosure
column9: Strict foreclosure is a court proceeding that gives the lender title directly, by court order, instead of giving cash proceeds from a public sale.  On default, the lender gives the borrower official notice.  After a prescribed period, the lender files suit in court, whereupon the court establishes a period within which the defaulting party must repay the amounts owed.  If the defaulter does not repay the funds, the court orders transfer of full, legal title to the lender

column3: A property owner gives Deanna permission to cross his property as a shortcut to her kindergarten school bus.  One day the property owner dies.  What right was Deanna granted originally, and will it survive the owner’s death?
column4: A personal easement in gross, which continues after the owner's death
column5: An easement by prescription, which continues after the owner's death
column6: A license, which continues after the owner's death
column7: A license, which terminates upon the owner's death
column9: A license is a personal right that a property owner grants to another to use the property for a specific purpose (to reach the kindergarten school bus). Unlike a personal easement in gross, which terminates only on the death of the grantee (Betty Luanne, in this instance), a license is revocable at any moment, is not transferable and does not attach to the land.  It ceases on the death of either party, or on the sale of the property

column3: On two adjacent properties, there is an easement that allows property A to use the driveway that belongs to property B.  After how many years will this become an easement by prescription?
column4: 7 years
column5: 10 years
column6: 15 years
column7: 20 years
column9: An easement by prescription is created after 20 years of open possession and use of another person’s property.

column3: A property owner who is selling her land wants to control how it is used in the future.  She might accomplish her aim by means of
column4: an injunction
column5: a deed restriction
column6: an easement
column7: a land trust
column9: A private party who wants to control the quality and standards of a property can establish a deed restriction.  Deed restrictions take precedence over zoning ordinances if they are more restrictive

column3: What distinguishes a lien from other types of encumbrance?
column4: It involves a monetary claim against the value of a property
column5: It lowers the value of a property
column6: It is created voluntarily by the property owner
column7: It attaches to the property rather than to the owner of the property
column9: A lien is a creditor's claim against personal or real property as security for a debt of the property owner.  If the owner defaults, the lien gives the creditor the right to force the sale of the property to satisfy the debt.  Liens do not necessarily alter the property value. Liens can be involuntary as well as voluntary.  Finally, liens attach to the property, but so do other encumbrances

column3: Which of the following defines actual notice?
column4: It is notice published in a newspaper
column5: It is knowledge one could have or should have obtained
column6: It is notice explicitly stated in a legal document
column7: It is knowledge received or imparted through direct experience
column9: The term "notice" is synonymous with "knowledge."  A person who has received actual notice has actual knowledge of something.  Receiving actual notice means learning of something through direct experience or communication. Thus, a document in itself cannot be actual notice. It is the seeing of the document that makes it actual notice

column3: Which of the following defines constructive notice?
column4: It is notice published in a newspaper
column5: It is knowledge one could have or should have obtained
column6: It is notice explicitly stated in a legal document
column7: It is knowledge received or imparted through direct experience
column9: Constructive notice, or legal notice, is knowledge of a fact that a person could have or should have obtained.  The foremost method of imparting constructive notice is by recordation of ownership documents in public records, specifically, title records. Since public records are open to everyone, the law generally presumes  that when evidence of ownership is recorded, the public at large has received constructive notice of ownership

column3: Ownership of real estate can be transferred voluntarily or involuntarily.  The three ways title can be  transferred voluntarily are by
column4: grant, deed, and will
column5: escheat, deed, and covenant
column6: title certificate, will, and deed
column7: sale contract, deed, and warrant of seizin
column9: Voluntary transfer, or voluntary alienation, is an unforced transfer of title by sale or gift from an owner to another party.  If the transferor is a government entity and the recipient is a private party, the conveyance is a public grant.  If the transferor is a private party, the conveyance is a private grant.  A living owner makes a private grant by means of a deed of conveyance, or deed.  A private grant that occurs when the owner dies is a transfer by will

column3: What is the function of recording a deed?
column4: It makes the deed valid
column5: It causes title to pass
column6: It gives constructive notice of ownership
column7: It removes all prior recorded encumbrances
column9: Recording is not necessary to make a deed valid.  However, it is in the grantee's best interests to do so.  Recording the deed gives the public constructive notice of the grantee's ownership

column3: The only clause that is actually required in a deed is the
column4: habendum clause
column5: granting clause
column6: reserving clause
column7: tenendum clause
column9: The granting, or premises, clause is the only required clause. It contains the conveyance intentions; names the parties; describes the property; and indicates a nominal consideration

column3: The type of deed that offers the grantee the fullest protection against claims to the title is the
column4: general warranty deed
column5: special warranty deed
column6: quitclaim deed
column7: bargain and defend deed
column9: The general warranty deed, or warranty deed for short, contains the fullest possible assurances of good title and protection for the grantee. The deed is technically a bargain and sale deed in which the grantor promises to defend against any and all claims to the title. The overall general warranty covenant is:  "I own and will defend."

column3: What is one of the purposes of a lawsuit to “quiet title”?
column4: To force the grantor to defend the title against a third party claim
column5: To terminate a co-ownership estate when one co-owner is unwilling
column6: To keep the owner's name out of the title records
column7: To have an encumbrance removed if the lienholder cannot prove its validity
column9: Where there is a possibility that prior errors in deeds or other recorded documents might cloud (encumber) the title, the relevant parties  execute a quitclaim deed to convey "any and all" interest to the grantee. If a party responsible for encumbering title refuses to quitclaim the interest, the owner may file a quiet title suit.  This requires the lienor to prove the validity of an interest.  If the defendant is unable to do so, the court removes the cloud by decree

column3: Which of the following best describes the documentary stamp tax?
column4: A transfer tax based on the price of the property being conveyed
column5: A tax a title company must pay in order to examine title records in the recorder's office
column6: A tax collected by attorneys and paid to the state when transfer documents are prepared
column7: A tax on stamps used to certify the authenticity of a conveyance
column9: State law usually requires payment of  a documentary stamp tax on a conveyance of real property.   The tax is based on the actual price of the property conveyed, thus enabling taxing authorities to ascertain current market value for ad valorem tax purposes.  Payment of the tax is evidenced on the deed

column3: The court proceeding that generally settles a decedent's estate is called
column4: testate
column5: probate
column6: escheat
column7: distribution
column9: A court proceeding called probate generally settles a decedent's estate, whether the person has died testate (having left a valid will) or intestate (having failed to do so)

column3: If an owner of real property dies intestate and has no legal heirs, what will happen to the property?
column4: It will escheat to the state or county
column5: It will transfer to the decedent's executor
column6: It will be divided equally among adjoining property owners
column7: It will become a public easement
column9: If an intestate decedent has no heirs, the estate escheats, or reverts, to the state or county after all claims and debts have been validated and settled

column3: A municipality wants to build a sewage treatment facility which will require the acquisition of several parcels of  privately owned land.  What legal power enables the municipality to buy the necessary properties, even against the owners’ wishes?
column4: Estoppel
column5: Escheat
column6: Alienation
column7: Eminent domain
column9: Various government and public entities can transfer private property to the public sphere by the power of eminent domain.  The transfer is involuntary, even though the owner receives compensation.  For example, a city government wants to widen a highway to accommodate growth.  The government uses eminent domain to condemn and purchase all properties abutting the thoroughfare in order to complete the construction project

column3: An adverse possessor must be able to successfully demonstrate that he or she has been
column4: openly possessing and claiming the property without the owner's consent
column5: occupying the property without an occupancy permit
column6: using the property intermittently and without permission over a period of years
column7: building a permanent structure on the property
column9: To claim legal title, the adverse possessor must be able to show a claim of right or color of title as reason for the possession; have notorious possession, which is possession without concealment; maintain a consistent claim of hostile possession, which is a claim to ownership and possession regardless of the owner's claims or consent; occupy the property continuously for a statutory period of time; in some states, pay taxes

column3: A buyer has signed a contract to purchase a property, but is uncertain of the condition of the title.  Which of the following parties is legally responsible for knowing the condition of the title?
column4: The County Recorder
column5: The seller's agent
column6: The buyer
column7: The mortgage lender
column9: Title records protect the buyer by revealing whether a property has marketable title, one free of undesirable encumbrances.  The buyer is legally responsible for knowing the condition of title, since it is a matter of public record

column3: A break in the chain of title to a property results in
column4: a clouded title
column5: a title plant
column6: a lien of indeterminate ownership
column7: a duplicate title
column9: Chain of title refers to the succession of property owners of record dating back to the original grant of title from the state to a private party.  If there is a missing link in the chronology of owners, or if there was a defective conveyance, the chain is said to be broken, resulting in a clouded title to the property

column3: Wayne and Leota obtain an insurance policy that protects them from liabilities and losses resulting from title defects.  The kind of policy they bought is a
column4: a homeowner's insurance policy
column5: standard owner's title insurance policy
column6: lender's title insurance policy
column7: private mortgage insurance policy
column9: An owner's policy may have standard coverage or extended coverage.  Standard coverage protects against title defects such as incompetent grantors, invalid deeds, fraudulent transaction documents, and defects in the chain of title.  Extended coverage protects against liabilities that may not be of public record, including fraud, unrecorded ownership claims, unintentional recording errors, and unrecorded liens

column3: An owner transfers title to a property to a buyer in exchange for a motorcycle.  This is an example of
column4: voluntary alienation
column5: involuntary liquidation
column6: hypothecation
column7: 1031 exchange
column9: Voluntary alienation is an unforced transfer of title by sale or gift from an owner to another party

column3: A person wishes to convey any and all interests in a property to another without assurance of the property’s marketability.  This party would most likely use which of the following types of deed?
column4: A sheriff's deed
column5: A special warranty deed
column6: A partition deed
column7: A quitclaim deed
column9: A quitclaim deed transfers real and potential interests in a property, whether an interest is known to exist or not.  The grantor makes no claim to any interest in the property being conveyed and offers no warrants to protect the grantee. Where there is a possibility that prior errors in deeds or other recorded documents might cloud (encumber) the title, the relevant parties execute a quitclaim deed to convey "any and all" interest to the grantee

column3: Jennifer owns a one-half interest in a condominium as a tenant in common with her business partner.  If Jennifer has several heirs and dies without a will, the property will
column4: pass to the heirs by the laws of descent and distribution
column5: escheat to the state
column6: pass to the surviving spouse based on homestead law
column7: pass to the surviving heirs according to the provisions of the will
column9: In this circumstance, the estate, including real property, will pass to lawful heirs according to the state's laws of descent and succession or distribution. These laws apportion the estate without regard to the wishes of the heirs or the intentions of the decedent. Escheat, by which the state takes the property, applies only if there are no legal heirs

column3: A drifter secretly lives in an abandoned shack on a large ranch property.  After twenty years, the person makes a claim of ownership to the shack and the land immediately surrounding it that he had cleared.  This claim will likely be
column4: upheld through adverse possession
column5: upheld because of the length of possession
column6: declined through the doctrine of prior appropriation
column7: declined because possession was secretive
column9: One of the preconditions for a claim of ownership based on adverse possession is notorious possession, or possession without concealment.  Even if the length of possession in this case meets the statutory requirement, the drifter’s secretiveness would invalidate the claim

column3: To be marketable, title must be
column4: insured
column5: free of undisclosed defects and encumbrances
column6: abstracted by an attorney
column7: guaranteed by a title certificate
column9: Marketable title is, by definition, one that is free and clear of undesirable and unknown encumbrances, claims, clouds, or other defects.  Attorney's abstracts and title certificates do not guarantee that a title is marketable

column3: A landlord generally has the right to enter the leased premises
column4: at any time without notice
column5: for specified reasonable purposes
column6: provided the tenant gives prior permission
column7: only thirty days prior to lease expiration
column9: A tenant has the sole right to occupy and use the premises without interference from outside parties, including the landlord.  The landlord may enter the premises for specified purposes such as inspections, but the interference must be reasonable and limited.  In addition, the landlord can do nothing outside of the lease's express provisions that would impair the tenant's enjoyment of income deriving from use of the premises

column3: When a tenant rents an apartment, he or she is usually responsible for
column4: compliance with the rules and regulations of the building
column5: payment for any alterations to the leased space
column6: recording the lease in title records
column7: occupying the premises throughout the lease term
column9: The lease defines the tenant's obligations, which principally are to pay the rent on time; maintain the property's condition; and comply with the rules and regulations of the building

column3: Under landlord-tenant laws, landlords must treat tenants fairly and honestly.  In a residential leasehold, this requirement would include
column4: insuring the tenant against loss of personal property
column5: providing required building support and services
column6: guaranteeing that a fair rent is being charged
column7: insuring the property for the value of the leasehold
column9: The lease defines the landlord's obligations, which principally are to provide the necessary building support and services, and maintain the condition of the property. It is the tenant's responsibility to obtain insurance and to determine the fairness of the rent

column3: While a one-year lease is in effect, the tenant dies of a sudden illness.  In this situation,
column4: the lease automatically terminates
column5: the tenant's estate has the option of canceling the contract
column6: the landlord can record a lien against the leased fee interest
column7: the tenant's estate is still obligated under the lease
column9: A valid lease creates obligations that survive the death of the landlord or tenant, with certain exceptions.  A tenant's estate remains liable for payment of rent if the tenant dies; the landlord's estate remains bound to provide occupancy despite the landlord's death
