column3: Three students rent a house together, and all three sign a one-year lease.  Six months later,  two students move out.  Which of the following is true of the remaining rent obligation?
column4: The remaining tenant is responsible for the full rent obligation
column5: The remaining tenant is responsible for one third of the rent obligation
column6: The lease is cancelled due to abandonment. Therefore, the rent obligation is extinguished
column7: The departing tenants have no further rent obligation
column9: Multiple tenants who sign a single lease are jointly and severally responsible for fulfilling lease obligations.  Thus, if one renter abandons an apartment, the other renters remain liable for rent

column3: A tenant transfers a portion of the leasehold interest to another party.  The instrument that accomplishes this transfer is a(n)
column4: deed
column5: novation
column6: sublease
column7: reconveyance
column9: Subletting (subleasing) is the transfer by a tenant, the sublessor, of a  portion of the leasehold interest to another party, the sublessee, through the execution of a sublease.  The sublease spells out all of the rights and obligations of the sublessor and sublessee, including the payment of rent to the sublessor.  The sublessor remains primarily liable for the original lease with the landlord.  The subtenant is liable only to the sublessor

column3: Vijay enters into a lease for his new store.  The provisions of the lease require Vijay to pay the operating expenses of the premises such as janitorial and repair expenses.  This is an example of a
column4: gross lease
column5: percentage lease
column6: land lease
column7: net lease
column9: A net lease requires a tenant to pay for utilities, internal repairs, and a proportionate share of taxes, insurance, and operating expenses in addition to rent.  In effect, the landlord "passes through" actual property expenses to the tenant rather than charging a higher rent level.  Net leases vary as to exactly what expenses the tenant is responsible for.  The purest form of net lease requires tenants to cover all expenses, including major repairs and property taxes

column3: A tenant obtains a full-service lease where the landlord agrees to pay all operating expenses in exchange for an additional $5.00 rent per square foot.  Another term for this lease is a(n)
column4: gross lease
column5: proprietary lease
column6: exchange lease
column7: full service net lease
column9: 2.49  A gross lease, or full service lease, requires the landlord to pay the property's operating expenses, including utilities, repairs, and maintenance, while the tenant pays only rent.  Rent levels under a gross lease are higher than under a net lease, since the landlord recoups expense outlays in the form of added rent

column3: Which of the following circumstances is the most likely scenario for a ground lease?
column4: A developer wants to acquire a necessary parcel that separates two parcels she already owns
column5: An owner-developer wants to retain ownership of the land portion of the improved real property
column6: A fast food company wants to place a restaurant in an existing building without buying either land or improvement
column7: A farmer wants to sell his property to a mining company
column9: Ground leases are primarily used when an owner wishes to lease raw land to an agricultural or mining interest; when unimproved property is to be developed and the owner wants to retain ownership of the land; when the developer or future users of the property do not want to own the land; or when the owner of an improved property wishes to sell an interest in the improvements while retaining ownership of the underlying land

column3: A tenancy at will can usually be terminated by
column4: either party giving proper notice
column5: either party without notice
column6: a sublease, with the lessor's approval
column7: an assignment by the lessor
column9: In the absence of an explicit term with beginning and ending date, a court will generally construe the lease to be a tenancy at will, cancelable upon proper notice

column3: Under the Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act, if a lease does not state a clear expiration date, the lease is regarded as
column4: invalid
column5: a tenancy from period-to-period
column6: a tenancy at will
column7: a tenancy for years
column9: URLTA sets standards for improving oral, vague, or unbalanced lease agreements.  In the case of an unclear lease expiration date, the lease is generally deemed to be a periodic tenancy

column3: The Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act generally does not apply to
column4: a hotel
column5: a single-family residence
column6: a unit in an apartment building that has fewer than ten units
column7: a duplex in which the owner occupies one of the units
column9: State laws based on URLTA generally do not apply to transient occupancies, such as hotel and motel rentals, proprietary leases in cooperatives, or to occupancy in a residence that is under a contract for deed

column3: In executing a condominium lease, a tenant has acquired
column4: a temporary transfer of legal title
column5: a limited freehold interest in the air space of her unit
column6: a temporary possessory interest
column7: a title conveyance in exchange for rent
column9: A lease is both an instrument of conveyance and a contract between principal parties to uphold certain covenants and obligations.  As a conveyance, a lease conveys an interest, called the leasehold estate, but does not convey legal title to the property. For this reason, a leasehold is also called a less-than-freehold estate

column3: When a tenant acquires a leasehold estate through a lease, what does the property owner acquire?
column4: A freehold estate for years
column5: A reduced leasehold estate
column6: A defeasible estate
column7: A leased fee estate
column9: In conveying the leasehold estate, the landlord acquires a leased fee estate, which entails the rights to: receive rent; re-possess the property following the lease term; and monitor the tenant's obligations to maintain the premises

column3: When an owner leases her property, she temporarily relinquishes the right to
column4: transfer the property
column5: encumber the property
column6: occupy the property
column7: maintain the property
column9: The legal essence of a valid lease is that it conveys an exclusive right to use and occupy a property for a limited period of time in exchange for rent and the return of the property after the lease term is over

column3: Which of the following happens when a leased property is sold?
column4: The buyer acquires title subject to the lease, which remains in effect
column5: The lease is cancelled
column6: The lease expires within thirty days unless renewed
column7: A new lease is automatically executed
column9: The landlord may sell, assign, or mortgage the leased fee interest.  However, transferring and encumbering the leased property do not extinguish the obligations and covenants of a lease.  Buyers and creditors, therefore, must take their respective interests subject to the terms of the lease

column3: If a lease does not state a specific ending date, when does it terminate?
column4: Immediately, since it is an invalid lease
column5: After one year
column6: When either party gives proper notice
column7: Whenever the property is sold
column9: In the absence of an explicit term with beginning and ending date, a court will generally construe the lease to be a tenancy at will, cancelable upon proper notice

column3: In accordance with the statute of frauds,
column4: leases in excess of one year must be recorded to be enforceable
column5: oral leases are not enforceable
column6: a five-year lease must be in writing to be enforceable
column7: an unwritten lease is fraudulent
column9: Generally, a lease for a period exceeding one year cannot be oral but must be in writing to be enforceable because of the statute of frauds

column3: Which of the following is true of a sublease?
column4: The subtenant takes over sole responsibility for performance of the original lease contract
column5: The original tenant retains primary responsibility for performance of the original lease contract
column6: It does not convey any of the leasehold interest
column7: It conveys the entire leasehold interest
column9: In a sublease-- a transfer of a portion of the leasehold-- the sublessor (original tenant) remains primarily liable for the original lease with the landlord.  The subtenant is liable only to the sublessor

column3: A legal description of a property is one which
column4: accurately identifies the boundaries of the property as distinct from all other properties
column5: accurately describes the location and dimensions the lot and  improvements on the property
column6: is accepted by a licensed surveyor as suitable for inclusion in a survey of the property
column7: is written by an attorney licensed to practice real estate law in the state in which the property is located
column9: A legal description of real property is one which accurately locates and identifies the boundaries of the subject parcel to a degree acceptable by courts of law in the state where the property is located. The general criterion for a legal description is that it alone provides sufficient data for a surveyor to locate the parcel.  A legal description identifies the property as unique and distinct from all other properties

column3: The essential elements of the metes and bounds system are
column4: parallels, base lines, and meridians
column5: boundaries, distances, and a base line
column6: reference points, angles, and distances
column7: lot numbers, sections, and ranges
column9: A metes and bounds description identifies the boundaries of a parcel of real estate using reference points, distances, and angles.  The description always identifies an enclosed area by starting at an origination point, called point of beginning, or POB, and returning to the POB at the end of the description

column3: In the Rectangular Survey System, a range is the area in between
column4: any row of sections in a township
column5: two consecutive meridians
column6: a principal meridian and a base line
column7: a parallel and a meridian
column9: The "vertical" area between consecutive meridians is called a range.  A range is identified by its relationship to the principal meridian.  All ranges are six miles wide

column3: In the Rectangular Survey System, a tier is defined by
column4: six consecutive sections of a township
column5: two consecutive meridians
column6: two consecutive parallels
column7: a parallel and a meridian
column9: The "horizontal" area between two parallels is called a tier, or a township strip.   A tier is identified by its relationship to the base parallel.  All tiers are six miles wide

column3: In the Rectangular Survey System, what are the dimensions of a township?
column4: One mile square
column5: Six miles by six miles, or 6 miles square
column6: Thirty-six miles square
column7: The north and south boundaries are one mile apart; the east and west boundaries are indeterminate
column9: A township is the area enclosed by the intersection of two consecutive meridians and two consecutive parallels.  Since the parallels and meridians are six miles apart, a township is a square with six miles on each side.  Its area is therefore 36 square miles.  Remember to differentiate square miles from miles square: 4 square miles is a measure of area (2 miles x 2 miles); 4 miles square is a representation of the sides of a square (4 miles by 4 miles)

column3: What portion of a section is ten acres?
column9: The size in acres of a subsection of a township is a fraction of 640 acres, since there are 640 acres in a section. Thus ten acres is 10/640, or 1/64th of a section

column3: The lot and block system of legally describing property is used for
column4: farm properties
column5: any property in an unincorporated area
column6: properties where metes and bounds is not acceptable
column7: properties in a subdivision
column9: The recorded plat method, also called the lot and block system, is used to describe properties in residential, commercial, and industrial subdivisions. Under this system, tracts of land are subdivided into lots.  The entire group of lots comprises the subdivision.  In a large subdivision, lots may be grouped together into blocks for ease of reference

column3: A certain legal description contains the phrase, "...northwesterly along  Erie Road to the POB...".  What kind of description is this?
column4: Plat survey
column5: Government grid
column6: Metes and bounds
column7: Rectangular survey
column9: A metes and bounds description identifies the point of beginning and describes the distance and direction from that point to the first monument, and thence to subsequent monuments and back to the beginning to define the property's enclosed perimeter

column3: How many sections are there in a township?
column4: One
column5: Six
column6: Twelve
column7: Thirty-six
column9: The rectangular survey system divides a township into thirty-six sections

column3: In the Rectangular Survey System, a section contains how many acres?
column9: Each side of a section is one mile in length.  Thus the area of a section is one square mile, or 640 acres

column3: The valuable consideration necessary to make a contract valid must be
column4: money
column5: something tangible
column6: something of value traded in exchange for something of value
column7: something of equal value with whatever is received in exchange
column9: A contract must contain a two-way exchange of valuable consideration as compensation for performance by the other party.  The contract is not valid or enforceable if just one party provides consideration.  Valuable consideration may be something of tangible value, such as money, or something the party promises to do. It may also be something intangible that a party must give up

column3: A real estate sales contract, to be enforceable, must
column4: contain a legal description of the property
column5: be written on a form approved by the state bar association
column6: be acknowledged by three witnesses
column7: be recorded within three days to be enforceable
column9: In addition to satisfying the requirements of a valid contract in general, a contract that conveys an interest in real estate must be in writing, contain a legal description of the property, and be signed by one or more of the parties

column3: How much time does a seller have to accept a buyer's offer?
column4: Forty-eight hours from the time of the offeror's signing of the offer
column5: Twenty-four hours from the time of the offer's delivery to the seller
column6: Within 24 hours following the stated expiration
column7: A reasonable time, or until the expiration date on the offer
column9: If an offer contains an expiration date and the phrase "time is of the essence," the offer expires at exactly the time specified.  In the absence of a stated time period, the offeree has a "reasonable" time to accept an offer

column3: A buyer submits an offer to a seller and then dies in a car accident.  Before learning of the buyer's death, the seller accepts the offer. Which of the following is true?
column4: The seller can force the buyer's estate to go through with the purchase
column5: The buyer's death terminated the offer
column6: The seller must make a new offer with the same terms to the buyer's heirs
column7: The buyer's heirs have the option of enforcing the contract
column9: Any of the following actions or circumstances can terminate an offer: acceptance; rejection; revocation; lapse of time; counteroffer; or death or insanity of either party

column3: Which of the following contracts can be assigned to another party?
column4: An exclusive listing agreement
column5: A personal services agreement
column6: A contract for the sale of undeveloped land
column7: An employment contract between a broker and a sales associate
column9: A real estate contract that is not a personal contract for services can be assigned to another party unless the terms of the agreement specifically prohibit assignment.  Listing agreements, for example, are not assignable, since they are personal service agreements between agent and principal.  Sales contracts, however, are assignable, because they involve the purchase of real property rather than a personal service

column3: An implied agency relationship may be deemed to exist if
column4: the parties do not disavow an express contract that has expired
column5: the parties act is if there is a contract
column6: an offering party does not receive written notice that the offer has been rejected
column7: the parties promise to perform their part of the agreement if the other party performs
column9: An implied contract is an unstated or unintentional agreement that may be deemed to exist when the actions of any of the parties suggest the existence of an agreement

column3: Which of the following is an executory contract?
column4: An expired lease
column5: A sale contract before closing
column6: A recorded sale contract
column7: An option to buy after it is exercised
column9: An executory contract is one in which performance is yet to be completed.  A sales contract prior to closing is executory: while the parties have agreed to buy and sell, the buyer has yet to pay the seller and the seller has yet to deed the property to the buyer

column3: A bilateral contract is one in which
column4: both parties promise to do something in exchange for the other party's performance
column5: both parties receive equal consideration
column6: two parties agree to perform a service together
column7: both parties promise to do something if the other party performs first
column9: A bilateral contract is one in which both parties promise to perform their respective parts of an agreement in exchange for performance by the other party.  An example of a bilateral contract is an exclusive listing: the broker promises to exercise due diligence in the efforts to sell a property,  and the seller promises to compensate the broker when and if the property sells

column3: A homeseller signs a listing agreement with a broker then subsequently revokes the listing.  Which of the following is true?
column4: The seller continues to have contractual obligations to the broker
column5: The contract remains in full force until the expiration date
column6: The broker may have a claim for marketing expenses expended during the listing term
column7: The seller cannot sign a listing agreement with another broker
column9: The damaged party may elect the following legal remedies: rescission; forfeiture; suit for damages; or suit for specific performance.  However, the broker must show that the seller has breached the contract

column3: A breach of contract is
column4: a termination of the contract by the mutual consent of the parties
column5: financial damage suffered by a party because another party has nullified a contract provision
column6: a lawsuit to force a party to discharge the contract
column7: the failure of a party to perform according to the terms of the contract
column9: A breach of contract is a failure to perform according to the terms of the agreement

column3: What is rescission?
column4: The act of withdrawing an offer before it has been accepted
column5: The act of declaring that a contract is no longer in effect for a given party
column6: The act of declaring a contract unenforceable
column7: The act of modifying the terms of an offer
column9: Parties to a contract may rescind a contract by mutual consent, or a damaged party may rescind the contract unilaterally.  This act of rescission cancels the contract and returns the parties to their pre-contract condition, including the refunding of any monies already transferred

column3: To be valid, a valid contract must
column4: reflect a mutual understanding or agreement
column5: use precise wording in a document
column6: not be executable
column7: be created only by an attorney
column9: Mutual consent, also known as offer and acceptance and meeting of the minds, requires that a contract involve a clear and definite offer and an intentional, unqualified acceptance of the offer

column3: Two parties enter into a contract.  The agreement fulfills all the requirements for a valid contract, with no disqualifying circumstances.  Given this situation, it is still possible that the contract may be
column4: void
column5: illegal
column6: unenforceable
column7: voidable
column9: A valid contract that is in writing is enforceable within a statutory time period.  A valid contract that is made orally is also generally enforceable within a statutory period, with the exception that some contracts are enforceable only if they are in writing.  These laws apply in particular to the transfer of interests in real estate. A void or voidable contract was not a truly valid contract

column3: The guardian for a mentally incompetent party enters into an oral contract with another party to buy a trade fixture on behalf of the incompetent party.  This contract
column4: does not meet validity requirements
column5: is possibly valid and enforceable
column6: must be in writing to be valid
column7: is valid but unenforceable
column9: Incompetent parties, or parties of "unsound mind," may not enter into enforceable contracts. However, during the period of one's incompetency, a court may appoint a guardian who may act on the incompetent party's behalf with court approval

column3: A prospective homebuyer submits a signed offer with the condition that the seller pay for the inspection at closing. The seller disagrees, crosses out the provision, then signs and returns the document to the buyer. At this point, assuming all other contract validity items are in order, the original offer is now
column4: an accepted offer, therefore a valid contract
column5: an executable option
column6: a counteroffer
column7: an invalid offer
column9: By changing any of the terms of an offer, the offeree creates a counteroffer, and the original offer is void.  At this point, the offeree becomes the offeror, and the new offeree gains the right of acceptance.  If accepted, the counteroffer becomes a valid contract provided all other requirements are met

column3: A construction contractor executes a contract with a buyer.  In the agreement, the contractor promises to complete construction by November 20.  This promise can be construed as
column4: an option
column5: mutual consent
column6: a meeting of the minds
column7: valuable consideration
column9: Valuable consideration can be something of tangible value, such as money, or something a party promises to do or not do.  For example, a home builder may promise to build a house for a party as consideration for receiving money from the home buyer

column3: A seller contracts to sell a property that she does not own.  The sale contract for this transaction
column4: is executable
column5: must be in writing
column6: is void
column7: is illegal yet potentially enforceable
column9: The content, promise, or intent of a contract must be lawful.  A contract that proposes an illegal act is void

column3: The statute of limitations requires that parties to a contract who have been damaged or who question the contract's provisions
column4: must act within a statutory period
column5: must select a specific, limited course of action for recouping their losses
column6: must arbitrate prior to taking court action
column7: must wait a statutory period before they may take legal action
column9: The statute of limitations restricts the time period for which an injured party in a contract has the right to rescind or disaffirm the contract.  A party to a voidable contract must act within the statutory period

column3: The purpose of the statute of frauds is to
column4: invalidate certain oral contracts
column5: require certain conveyance-related contracts to be in writing
column6: nullify oral leases and listing agreements
column7: eliminate fraud in real estate contracts
column9: The statute of frauds requires that certain contracts must be in writing to be enforceable.  Real estate contracts that convey an interest in real property fall in this category, with the exception that a lease of one year's duration or less may be oral

column3: A seller immediately accepts a buyer's offer but waits ten days before returning the accepted document to the buyer.  Meanwhile, the offer has expired.  Which of the following is true?
column4: The buyer is bound to the contract since it was accepted immediately
column5: The buyer has no obligations to the seller whatsoever
column6: The buyer may not rescind the expired offer
column7: The seller may sue for specific performance
column9: The mutual consent required for a valid contract is reached through the process of offer and acceptance.  If the offeree accepts all terms without amendment, the offer becomes a contract.  The exact point at which the offer becomes a contract is when the offeree gives the offeror notice of the acceptance. If an offer contains an expiration date and the phrase "time is of the essence," the offer expires at exactly the time specified

column3: When a broker enters into a listing agreement, the broker has agreed to accept which of the following?
column4: Fiduciary and contractual obligations with the client
column5: Fiduciary relationships with client and customer
column6: Contractual obligations with cooperating brokers
column7: Fiduciary obligations with the customer
column9: A listing agreement establishes an agency relationship between agent and client that commits the agent to the full complement of fiduciary duties to the client in fulfilling the agreement

column3: The degree of authority granted by a residential brokerage listing agreement generally allows the agent to
column4: create contractual obligations for the client
column5: negotiate the selling price between client and customer
column6: hire inspectors, and other individuals to prepare the property for marketing
column7: market, sell and show the property
column9: Special agency limits the scope of the broker's authority to specific activities, generally those which generate customers and catalyze the transaction.  A special agency agreement usually does not authorize a broker to obligate the client to a contract as a principal party.   Normally, principals do not delegate the authority to negotiate price to an agent in a residential transaction

column3: A sales associate, without an oral or written listing agreement, brings potential buyers to the seller.  The seller says, "You can bring me buyers if you want, but I'm not paying you a commission."  The sales associate then continues to direct buyers to the property.  Which of the following is true about this situation?
column4: There is no agency relationship, and therefore the seller will owe no commission if one of the sales associate's buyers buys the property
column5: An implied agency may have been created, with obligations to perform for both seller and agent
column6: The seller and agent have an illegal, undisclosed agency relationship
column7: The agent has an open exclusive agency listing with no commission agreement, and therefore owes no fiduciary duties to the seller
column9: Clients and agents may also create an implied agency listing based on substantive actions rather than on an express agreement.  For example, if a seller allows a broker to undertake certain activities toward effecting a transaction without a specific authorization, but with full knowledge and consent, an implied agency may have been created

column3: An agent enters into a listing agreement with a homeseller, but then becomes too busy to professionally fulfill the terms of the agreement.  To solve the dilemma, the agent assigns the agreement to another licensee in the office.  Which of the following is true about this situation?
column4: The agent cannot assign the listing agreement
column5: The new listing agent acquires the full set of fiduciary duties owed to the client
column6: The new broker has to split any commission that results with the assigning broker
column7: The original broker has to disclose the assignment to the seller
column9: Since a listing agreement is a personal service contract, it is not assignable.   In particular, a broker cannot assign a listing to another broker

column3: From an agent's point of view, the most desirable form of listing agreement is a(n)
column4: exclusive agency
column5: exclusive right to sell
column6: open listing
column7: net listing
column9: The exclusive right to sell listing, or "exclusive,"  gives the agent the most control over the property and the greatest likelihood of being compensated for his or her marketing efforts

column3: What is a multiple listing?
column4: A listing shared by a listing agent and a selling agent
column5: A listing that a listing agent delegates to a subagent
column6: A listing that is entered in a multiple listing service to enable cooperation with member brokers
column7: A listing that authorizes a listing agent to market more than one property for a seller
column9: Though not a distinct type of listing agreement, multiple listing is a significant feature of brokerage practice.  Multiple listing is an authorization to enter a listing in a multiple listing service

column3: Which of the following conditions is necessary for a customer to qualify as “ready, willing, and able” in the context of a commissionable transaction?
column4: The customer's offer must be accepted
column5: The customer must be legally competent to undertake the transaction
column6: The customer must have a commitment from a lender
column7: The customer must have no business relationship with the agent
column9: Effecting a completed transaction means finding a customer who is not only ready, willing, and able, but one who makes an acceptable offer.  A ready, willing, and able customer is one who is: amenable to the terms of the transaction (ready and willing), and is financially capable of paying the price and legally capable of completing the transaction (able)

column3: Although a listing broker may delegate listing tasks to an employed licensee, the broker may not delegate the authority to
column4: obtain and distribute compensation
column5: provide cooperating brokers with information about the property
column6: advertise the property
column7: inspect the property for hazardous substances
column9: In the normal course of business, a listing broker delegates marketing responsibilities to sales associates and broker associates.  A sales associate or broker associate may not, however, seek compensation directly from a client.  Only the broker can obtain and disburse the compensation

column3: Agent Peter has an open listing with Frank. Paul is Peter's broker. Agent Perry's customer buys Frank's house. Patrick has a commission agreement with Frank.  Who is most likely to be compensated in this scenario?
column4: Peter, since he has a written listing agreement
column5: Paul, since he is Peter's broker
column6: Perry, since he found the customer
column7: Patrick, since he has a commission agreement
column9: The two principal determinants of procuring cause are being first to find the customer, and being the one who induces the customer to complete the transaction

column3: If an agent has an exclusive listing to sell a property, and the property is then taken by eminent domain, what is the status of the listing?
column4: The seller's obligations under the listing are assigned to the agency that takes the property
column5: It becomes a voidable contract
column6: The commission clause of the agreement is canceled
column7: It may be terminated against the agent's will
column9: A listing may terminate on grounds of: performance; infeasibility; mutual agreement; revocation; abandonment; breach; lapse of time; invalidity of the contract; incapacitation of either party; destruction of the property; or, in this case; involuntary title transfer

column3: A broker obtains an exclusive listing to sell a house, but after two months, he abandons the listing because the seller is too demanding and hot-tempered.  What can the seller do in this situation?
column4: Have the licensee’s license revoked for negligence
column5: Sue the broker for money damages
column6: Sign a listing agreement with another broker and force the first broker to pay the commission
column7: Force the broker to perform the contract without compensation
column9: If the broker cancels the listing or otherwise defaults, the client may sue the broker for money damages

column3: An owner agrees to pay a broker for procuring a tenant unless it is the owner who finds the tenant.  This is an example of a(n)
column4: exclusive right-to sell agreement
column5: exclusive agency agreement
column6: open listing
column7: net listing
column9: An exclusive agency listing authorizes a single broker to sell the property and earn a commission, but leaves the owner the right to sell the property without the broker's assistance, in which case no commission is owed

column3: A landlord promises to compensate a broker for procuring a tenant, provided the broker is the procuring cause.  This is an example of a(n)
column4: exclusive right-to rent agreement
column5: exclusive agency agreement
column6: open rental listing
column7: net lease listing
column9: An open listing is a non-exclusive authorization to sell or lease a property.  The owner may offer such agreements to any number of brokers in the marketplace.  With an open listing, the broker who is the first to perform under the terms of the listing is the sole party entitled to a commission

column3: A property owner agrees to pay a broker an open-ended commission as the difference between the sale price and a net amount, provided the owner receives a minimum amount of proceeds from the sale at closing.  This is an example of a(n)
column4: exclusive right-to sell agreement
column5: exclusive agency agreement
column6: open listing
column7: net listing
column9: A net listing is one in which an owner sets a minimum acceptable amount to be received from the transaction and allows the broker to have any amount received in excess as a commission, assuming the broker has earned a commission according to the other terms of the agreement

column3: In the context of agency law, the legal difference between an owner representation agreement and a buyer representation agreement is
column4: the client
column5: the commission amount
column6: fiduciary duties
column7: regulatory approvals
column9: Generally, buyer and tenant representation agreements are subject to the same laws and regulations as those applying to owner listings. The only difference is the client and his or her transaction expectations

column3: A multiple listing authorization gives a broker what authority?
column4: To list the owner's property in a multiple listing service
column5: To sell several properties for the owner at once
column6: To represent both seller and buyer, if necessary, in selling the property
column7: To delegate the listing responsibilities to other agents
column9: A multiple listing is not a distinct listing contract but rather a provision in an exclusive listing authorizing the broker to place the listing into a multiple listing service.  A multiple listing service is an organization of member brokers who agree to cooperate in the sale of properties listed by other brokers in exchange for a share of the broker's resulting commission

column3: A real estate sale contract is an executory contract until
column4: the completed sale transaction is recorded
column5: the buyer and seller have agreed to all provisions and have signed the contract
column6: all the obligations and promises are performed and the transaction is closed
column7: the loan has been approved, the title insurance has been obtained, and the closing date is set
column9: An executory contract is one for which the signatories have yet to perform their respective obligations and promises.  Upon closing, the sale contract is fully performed and no longer exists as a binding agreement

column3: In assisting a buyer or seller to complete an offer to purchase, what should an agent do to reduce the risk of committing an unauthorized practice of law?
column4: Use a standard contract promulgated by a state agency or a real estate board
column5: Observe ethical standards promulgated by real estate trade organizations
column6: Offer legal advice only on points of the contract that the agent is absolutely certain about
column7: Write contract terms that are fair to both buyer and seller
column9: It is advisable, and legally required in most states, for a broker to use a standard contract form promulgated by state agencies or real estate boards, as such forms contain generally accepted language.  This relieves the broker of the dangers of creating new contract language, which can be construed as a practice of law for which the broker is not licensed

column3: To be enforceable, a contract for the conveyance of real estate must
column4: be acknowledged by witnesses
column5: be written
column6: be recorded
column7: have an expiration date
column9: A contract for the sale of real estate is enforceable only if it is in writing.  A buyer or seller cannot sue to force the other to comply with an oral contract for sale, even if the contract is valid

column3: A buyer makes an offer to purchase a house, and the seller accepts the offer. However, before the sales associate can inform the buyer of the seller’s decision, the buyer delivers a written notice that she is opting out and cancelling the agreement. At this point, which of the following is true?
column4: The contract has been legitimately cancelled and is null and void
column5: The seller must give the buyer an opportunity to make a new offer
column6: The buyer must perform under the terms of the contract
column7: The seller must notify the buyer in writing that the buyer is in default
column9: To be valid, a contract must meet the criteria of: competent parties, voluntary act of good faith, mutual consent, legal purpose, and valuable consideration. The buyer broke the mutual consent requirement by opting out before being told of the seller’s acceptance. Thus, there is no valid contract

column3: Which of the following is an essential element of a valid contract for the sale of real estate?
column4: A valid blank form that the contract is written on
column5: A habitable property
column6: An offer and acceptance
column7: A marketable title
column9: A contract of sale is created by full and unequivocal acceptance of an offer. Offer and acceptance satisfy the mutual consent requirement for a valid contract. The offeree must accept the offer without making any changes whatsoever

column3: What kind of interest does the buyer acquire once a real estate sale contract is signed by the principal parties?
column4: Legal title
column5: Lienholder interest
column6: Reversionary interest
column7: Equitable title
column9: A sale contract gives the buyer an interest in the property that is called equitable title, or ownership in equity.  If the seller defaults and the buyer can show good faith performance, the buyer can sue for specific performance, that is, to compel the seller to transfer legal title upon payment of the contract price

column3: A contingency in a sale contract is
column4: a promise by buyer or seller to perform a specific action
column5: a condition that, if unmet, renders the contract unenforceable
column6: one of several alternative actions that buyer or seller may take to satisfy contract requirements
column7: an optional, unilateral action that either party may take at the request of the other party
column9: A contingency is a condition that must be met before the contract is enforceable. If one party cannot meet a contingency condition by a specified deadline, the other party may cancel the contract

column3: A clause in a sale contract stipulates that the seller must provide evidence that the property is free of active termite infestation.  On the day of closing, the buyer learns that inspection service did not provide the required written documentation.   The buyer then proceeds to declare that the sale is off.  Which of the following is true of this situation?
column4: The seller can sue for specific performance
column5: The buyer will be in default, and liable for damages, if he does not complete the transaction
column6: The buyer may be able to have the contract canceled
column7: The contract is automatically void
column9: The termite inspection clause is a contingency clause. If one party cannot meet a contingency condition by a specified deadline, the other party may cancel the contract.  Did the clause state that the inspector had to be properly licensed?  If so, the buyer has a good case for cancellation

column3: A buyer signs an earnest money agreement and gives it to the broker who showed her the property she is buying.  After leaving the broker's office, she reconsiders and decides she prefers a different property.  How long does she have to take back her offer?
column4: Until the seller communicates acceptance of the offer
column5: Until the earnest money deposit check is cashed
column6: She can take it back at any time, but must forfeit the earnest money
column7: She cannot take it back until after the expiration date of the offer
column9: An offeror may revoke an offer for any reason prior to communication of acceptance by the offeree

column3: On Wednesday, Fred offers to sell his property to Jack for $275,000, with the offer to remain open until 5 p.m. the next day.  On Thursday morning, Sally offers Fred $280,000 for the property and Fred accepts.  At 1 p.m. on Thursday afternoon, Jack accepts.  Which of the following is true of this situation?
column4: The acceptance by Sally creates a contract and terminates Fred's offer to Jack
column5: Fred has entered into contracts with both Jack and Sally to sell the same property
column6: Fred's acceptance of Sally's offer is invalidated by Jack's acceptance, because Fred's offer to Jack was made prior to Sally's offer to Fred
column7: No contract has been created because it is impossible to have two valid sale contracts for the same property
column9: Jack's acceptance of Fred's offer creates a valid contract, just as Fred's acceptance of Sally's offer creates a valid contract.  Fred should have revoked his offer to Jack before accepting Sally's offer

column3: Among the items that normally must be disclosed in a sale contract or its addenda is/are  the
column4: buyer's financial capability
column5: buyer's source of funds for the down payment
column6: seller’s acceptable price range
column7: agency relationships and property condition
column9: It is common for the seller to disclose the property condition requiring the buyer to acknowledge receipt of the disclosure. The broker discloses the applicable agency relationships in the transaction and names the party who must pay the brokerage commission

column3: To create an enforceable option-to-buy contract, there must be an exchange of
column4: a promise to sell and a promise to buy
column5: valuable consideration and a right to buy
column6: valuable consideration and a promise to buy
column7: a down payment and a post-dated contract for sale
column9: An option-to-buy is an enforceable contract in which a potential seller, the optionor, grants a potential buyer, the optionee, the right to purchase a property before a stated time for a stated price and terms.  In exchange for the right of option, the optionee pays the optionor valuable consideration

column3: Mary Carboy buys a house from Jim Schmidt and at the same time obtains an option to purchase the adjoining vacant lot for $10,000 within one year. A few months later, Carboy informs Schmidt that she is ready to exercise her option, but finds that Schmidt has received an offer of $12,000 from another party.  Schmidt states that he will accept the offer unless Carboy is willing to match the $12,000 offer.  Which of the following is true of this situation?
column4: Schmidt must sell to Carboy for $10,000
column5: Carboy must pay $12,000 or lose the property
column6: Schmidt may sell to Carboy or the other party, but the price cannot exceed $10,000
column7: If the other party delivers payment before Carboy does, the option is canceled
column9: Mary's option-to-buy contract is enforceable, assuming she paid a consideration for it

column3: Which of the following is true regarding the assignability of an option?
column4: It is assignable only if the contract specifically allows assignment
column5: It is never assignable
column6: It is assignable only if the option is exercised
column7: It is always assignable unless the contract prohibits assignment
column9: A real estate contract that is not a personal service contract can be assigned to another party unless the terms of the agreement specifically prohibit assignment. An option-to-buy is therefore assignable in the absence of such a prohibiting clause

column3: Which of the following is true of a contract for deed transaction?
column4: At the end of the contract period, the vendee receives equitable title, provided all required periodic payments have been made
column5: The vendee has no right to possess or occupy the property during the contract period
column6: At the end of the contract period, the vendor conveys legal title, provided the vendee has fulfilled all obligations
column7: The vendor may cancel the contract at any time before the final payment has been received
column9: A contract for deed is a bilateral agreement between a seller, the vendor, and a buyer, the vendee, in which the vendor defers receipt of some or all of the purchase price of a property over a specified period of time. At the end of the period, the buyer completes payment to the vendor of the full purchase price and the vendor deeds legal title to the vendee

column3: Several buyers are competing for the last available home in a desirable new subdivision.  One buyer calls the owner-developer directly on the phone and offers $20,000 over and above the listed price.  The developer accepts the offer.  At this point,
column4: the parties have a valid, enforceable sale contract on the home
column5: the parties have completed a verbal, executory contract
column6: the parties may not cancel their contract
column7: the developer could not entertain other offers on the property
column9: As a sale contract created by an offer and acceptance,  the parties have an executory contract: the parties have yet to perform their respective obligations and promises.  However,  as a contract for the sale of real estate, this verbal contract is not enforceable. An enforceable real estate sale contract must be in writing

column3: An owner completes a sales contract on her property with a buyer.  Before closing, the seller runs into financial trouble and assigns the contract to her principal creditor.  The buyer cries foul, fearing the property will be lost.  Which of the following is true?
column4: The buyer can sue the assignee to disallow the illegal assignment
column5: The buyer can take legal action against the assignor
column6: The assignor has completed a legal action
column7: The sale contract is nullified
column9: Either party to a sale transaction can assign the sale contract to another party, subject to the provisions and conditions contained in the agreement

column3: A due-on-sale clause in a sale contract puts parties on notice that
column4: the full price of the property is due the seller at closing
column5: any loans surviving closing become immediately payable
column6: all of the seller's debts must be retired before or upon closing
column7: any conveyance may trigger an acceleration of any loans secured by the property
column9: The mortgage agreement may or may not state that the seller's loan will be accelerated by the lender and called due on sale. The due-on-sale clause in the sale contract merely stipulates that the buyer and seller recognize the possibility that loans that survive the closing may be called due

column3: A tenant has an option-to-purchase agreement with the landlord that expires on June 30.  On July 1, the tenant frantically calls the landlord to exercise the option, offering the apology that she was busy with a death in the family.  Which of the following is true?
column4: Since options contain grace periods, the landlord must sell
column5: The tenant loses the right to buy, but can claim the money paid for the option from the landlord
column6: The landlord does not have to sell, but must renew the option
column7: The option is expired, and the tenant has no rightful claim to money paid for the option
column9: The option automatically expires at the end of the option period.  The landlord has no obligation, either to sell the property or to return the consideration, after the expiration date

column3: Two parties enter into a contract for deed agreement.  In this form of agreement,
column4: title is conveyed to the buyer, but the seller retains possession for a stipulated time period
column5: the buyer contracts to pay all cash at closing in exchange for the deed
column6: the seller retains legal title while the buyer makes partial payments until the contract is fully executed
column7: the buyer immediately acquires legal title and takes possession
column9: In a contract for deed, the seller, or vendor, defers receipt of some or all of the purchase price of a property over a specified period of time.  During the period, the vendor retains legal title and the vendee acquires equitable title. At the end of the period, the buyer pays the vendor the full purchase price and the vendor deeds legal title to the vendee

column3: What is a lien-theory state?
column4: A state in which a mortgagee holds legal title to a secured property
column5: A state in which a mortgagee has equitable title to a secured property
column6: A state that allows a real estate owner's creditors to record liens against the owner's property
column7: A state in which a lien is considered as a conveyance
column9: States differ in their interpretation of who owns mortgaged property. Those that regard the mortgage as a lien held by the mortgagee (lender) against the property owned by the mortgagor (borrower) are called lien-theory states.  Those that regard the mortgage document as a conveyance of ownership from the mortgagor to the mortgagee are called title-theory states

column3: What is the function of a note in a mortgage or trust deed financing arrangement?
column4: It is the lender's security instrument  in the collateral property

column3: If a borrower obtains an interest-only loan of $200,000 at an annual interest rate of 6%, what is the monthly interest payment?
column9: Multiply the rate times the loan amount and divide by 12 to calculate monthly interest.  Thus, ($200,000 x 6%) ÷ 12 = $1,000

column9: The equation for the loan amount is (annual interest divided by the interest rate) = loan amount.  Thus, ($500 x 12) ÷  .06 = $100,000

column3: A borrower of a $50,000 interest-only loan makes annual interest payments of $3750.  What interest rate is the borrower paying?
column9: The equation for the interest rate is (annual payment / loan amount) = interest rate.  Thus ($3750 / $50,000) = 7.5%

column9: In an amortizing loan, part of the principal is repaid periodically along with interest, so that the principal balance decreases over the life of the loan. The annual interest is never the same, since the principal balance to which the interest rate applies changes every year.  Interest on a loan is always paid in arrears, not in advance

It does, however, apply to refinancing of mortgage loans, and to home equity loans.  State law may require a rescission period and notice on first mortgage loan transactions as well

column9: Loan underwriting is the process of assessing the lender's risk in giving a loan.  Mortgage underwriting includes: evaluating the borrower's ability to repay the loan; appraising the value of the property offered as security; and determining the terms of the loan

column3: The three overriding considerations of a lender's mortgage loan decision are
column4: points, interest rate, and loan term
column5: the location of the mortgaged property, the borrower's cash, and the amount of the borrower's equity
column6: the ability to re-pay, the value of the collateral, and the profitability of the loan
column7: the amount of the loan, the borrower's income, and the down payment
column9: A lender assesses risks by examining, or qualifying, both borrower and property.  In qualifying a borrower, an underwriter weighs the ability of the borrower to repay the loan. In qualifying a property, an underwriter assesses the ability of the property value to cover potential losses.  In this evaluation, a lender requires that the appraised value of the property be more than adequate to cover the contemplated loan and costs. Finally, the loan must make money for the lending organization as a basic business precept

column3: The reason lenders consider the loan-to-value ratio important in underwriting is that
