column3: Mack is buying Roy’s house for $500,000. Mack’s loan amount is $325,000.  He has agreed to pay 1.5 points at closing.  How much will Mack pay for points?
column9: $325,000 x .015 = $4,875.  Remember, one point = 1% of the loan amount

column3: A lender determines that a homebuyer can afford to borrow $130,000 on a mortgage loan.  The lender requires an 80% loan-to-value ratio.  How much can the borrower pay for a property and still qualify for this loan amount?
column9: Use the formula: Price x LTV Ratio = Loan.  Then plug in the figures and calculate: Price x .80 = $130,000.  Therefore, Price = $130,000 / .80 = $162,500

column3: Home buyer Janet pays $1,600 / month for the interest-only loan on her new house.  The loan’s interest rate is 6.75%.  If she obtained a 75% loan, what was the purchase price?
column9: First, the annual interest paid is $1,600 x 12, or $19,200.  The interest rate is 6.75%.  Using the formula (Loan = Interest / Rate), the loan amount is $19,200 / 6.75%, or $284,444.  As this is 75% of the price, the price is ($284,444 / .75), or $379,259

column3: Loan applicant Taylor has an annual gross income of $76,000. How much will a lender allow Taylor to pay for monthly housing expense to qualify for a loan if the lender uses an income ratio of 30%?
column9: Monthly income qualification is derived by multiplying monthly income by the income ratio.  Thus (76,000 / 12) x .30 = $1,900.  Remember to first derive the monthly income

column3: An investor paid $80,000 for a lot and $600,000 to have an apartment building constructed on it.  He has depreciated the property for the past 10 years on a 39-year straight-line schedule.  If he sells the property this year and realizes $780,000, what is his capital gain?
column9: Total depreciation on this property = ($600,000 / 39 years) x 10 years, or $153,846.  His adjusted basis is therefore ($680,000 original price – 153,846 depreciation taken), or $526,154.  The gain is then ($780,000 – 526,154), or $253,846

column3: A homeowner bought a house five years ago for $250,000.  Since then, the homeowner has spent $2,000 to build a screened porch and has added a central air-conditioning system at a cost of $5,000.  What is the homeowner's adjusted basis if the house is sold today?
column9: Adjusted basis = beginning basis ($250,000) + capital improvements ($2,000 + $5,000) – depreciation (0) =  adjusted basis ($257,000)

column3: A homeowner sold her house and had net proceeds of $265,000.  Her adjusted basis in the home was $231,000. She immediately bought another house for $301,000.  What was her capital gain?
column7: None
column9: Capital gain =  amount realized (net sales proceeds, $265,000) - adjusted basis ($231,000) = ($34,000)

column3: Debra bought a home for $120,000, paying $24,000 down and taking a mortgage loan of $96,000.  The following year she had a new roof put on, at a cost of $5,000.  What is Debra's adjusted basis in the house if she now sells the house for $150,000?
column9: The basic formula for adjusted basis is: Beginning Basis + Capital Improvements - Exclusions and Credits = Adjusted Basis. Debra's adjusted basis is therefore $120.000 + $5,000 = $125,000. The financing terms and subsequent selling price are not relevant

column3: A certain investor wants an 11% return on investment from any real estate investment.  A property priced at $360,000 has gross income of $60,000 and expenses of $22,000.  Approximately how much too high or too low is the price of this property for the investor to obtain her desired return exactly?
column4: $1,000 overpriced
column5: $8,000 underpriced
column6: $15,000 overpriced
column7: $16,000 underpriced
column9: Use the same formula V = I / R where V is the price and R is the rate of return.  Then plug in the numbers to solve for V. The NOI of this property is ($60,000  - $22,000), or $38,000.  The return is 11%.  Therefore, the value to get this return must be $38,000 / .11, or $345,455.  Since the price is $360,000, the price exceeds the amount needed for an 11% return by approximately $15,000 ( $360,000 - $345,455 = $14,545)

column3: An office building investor sees a listing of an office building which is priced at $2 million.  He loves the property, but he knows he needs to make a return of at least 8% to satisfy his partners.  If the building is 25,000 SF, rents for $10/SF per year, has 5% vacancy, and annual expenses of $70,000, should he buy it?  What is his return?
column4: No, since he will yield 2.00%
column5: Yes, since he will yield 8.375%
column6: Yes, since he will yield 8%
column7: Yes, since he will yield 9.125%
column9: Use the same formula R = I / V where V is the $2 million price, and R is the cap rate or rate of return.  To identify income: (25,000 SF x $10/SF) = $250,000 gross income, minus 5% vacancy (.05 x $250,000), or $12,500, minus expenses of $70,000 = $167,500 net income. ($250,000 – 12,500 – 70,000)   Now divide net income of $167,500 by $2,000,000 to derive the return of  8.375%

column3: Chad owns a small retail property that he inherited from his father.  There are no mortgages or interest expenses connected with the property.  Chad takes an annual cost recovery expense of $7,000. The property has a monthly gross income of $1,650 and monthly operating expenses of $600. Chad's taxable income from this property will be taxed at a rate of 30%.  What is the tax liability for the year?
column9: Annual gross operating income ($1,650 x 12 = $19,800) - annual operating expenses ($600 x 12 = $7,200) = annual net operating income ( $12,600); annual net operating income ($12,600) - cost recovery expense ($7,000) = taxable income ($5,600); taxable income ($5,600) x tax rate (30%) = tax liability ($1,680)

column3: A property has a net income of $150,000, interest payments of $105,000, principal payments of $30,000, and annual cost recovery of $7,000.  The property's tax rate is 28%.  What is the property's annual tax on income?
column9: The basic formula for tax liability is: Taxable Income x Tax Rate =  Tax Liability. Taxable Income is Net Operating Income - Interest Expense - Cost Recovery Expense.  Therefore, the annual tax is  $150,000 (NOI) - $105,000 (Interest Expense) - $7,000 (Cost Recovery Expense)  x 28% =  $10,640.  Note that the principal payment is not deductible in calculating taxable income

column3: An investor bought 4 oversized lots in order to subdivide.  He paid $70,000 for the lots.  After subdividing, the investor was able to sell each lot for $23,000.  Excluding commissions and closing costs, what per cent profit did the investor realize?
column9: The formula for profit % is (profit / initial investment).  The profit made was ($23,000 x 4) – 70,000 initial investment, or $22,000.  Dividing this by the amount invested derives a profit percent of 31.4%

column3: A school district's tax rate is 10 mills.  The school district's required revenue from taxes is $10,000,000.  What is the tax base of the area?
column9: The mill rate = (tax requirement  / the tax base).  A mill is one one-thousandth of a dollar ($.001).  To solve for the tax base, reconfigure this formula to be: Base = Tax Requirement / Mill Rate.  Thus the Base = $10,000,000 / .010, or $1,000,000,000

column3: A homeowner's residence has an assessed valuation of $140,000, and a market value of $170,000.  The homestead exemption is $25,000.  Tax rates for the property are 7 mills for schools; 3 mills for the city; 2 mills for the county; and 1 mill for the local community college.  What is the homeowner's tax bill?
column9: First, always use the assessed valuation, not the market value.  Subtract out the homestead exemption to derive taxable value, or $140,000 – 25,000 = $115,000.  As a shortcut to calculating the tax bill, simply add up all the mills, multiply them times .001 to convert mills to decimals, then multiply this number times the taxable value.  Thus (7 + 3 + 2 + 1) x .001 x $115,000 = $1,495

column3: The village of Goodsprings has an annual budget requirement of $8,000,000 to be funded by property taxes.  Assessed valuations are $400,000,000, and exemptions total $25,000,000.  What must the tax rate be to finance the budget?

A property has sold for $127,000.  The listing agreement calls for a commission of 7%.  The listing broker and selling broker agree to share the commission equally.  What will the listing agent receive if the agent is scheduled to get a 40% share from his broker?
column9: First calculate the total commission, then the co-brokerage splits, then the agent-broker split.  Thus: $127,000 x 7% = $8,890 total commission.  ($8,890 x 50%) = $4,445 total listing broker share.  ($4,445 x 40% = $1,778 agent's share

column3: Kevin, who works for selling broker Paul, sells a house listed by listing broker Adams.  The house sells for $325,000.  The co-brokerage split between Paul and Adams is 50-50.  Kevin is on a 65% commission schedule with Paul.  If the total commission rate is 6.5%, what is Kevin's commission?
column9: Figure the total commission, then the co-brokerage splits, then the broker-agent splits.  Thus, ($325,000 x 6.5%) = $21,125.  ($21,125 x 50%) = $10,563.  ($10,563 x .65) = $6,866

column3: A sale transaction closes on April 1, the ninety-first day of the tax year.  The day of closing belongs to the seller.  Real estate taxes for the year, not yet billed, are expected to be $3,150.  According to the 365-day method, what should appear on the closing statement?
column4: A debit to the buyer and credit to the seller for $2,364.62
column5: A debit to the buyer and credit to the seller for $785.34
column6: A credit to the buyer and debit to the seller for $785.34
column7: A credit to the buyer and debit to the seller for $2,364.62
column9: The daily tax expense, first, is ($3,150 / 365) or $8.63.  Since the buyer will pay the taxes after closing, the seller must pay the buyer his or her portion of the tax bill at closing, which is the 91 days from the beginning of the year through closing.  Therefore, credit the buyer and debit the seller ($8.63 x 91), or $785.34

column3: Alexis is buying Jack’s house. The closing date (day belongs to seller) of the sale transaction is September 1 (day 244 of the year). Her loan has a monthly payment of $577.84, with $525 going to interest in the first month. At closing, Alexis must pre-pay interest for the period of Sept. 2-Sept. 30.  Use the 365-day method for prorating.  What is her prepaid interest amount?
column9: If the buyer pays $525 interest for 30 days, the daily expense is ($525 / 30), or $17.50.  If there are 29 days of pre-paid expense, the buyer's charge is ($17.50 x 29), or $507.50

column3: A sale transaction on rental property closes on December 16.  The landlord received the December rent of $1,380 on December 1.  Assuming the closing day is the buyer's, and that the 365-day method is used for prorating, which of the following entries would appear on the settlement statement?
column4: Debit seller $667.74
column5: Credit seller $1,380.00
column6: Debit buyer $712.26
column7: Credit buyer $712.26
column9: For the monthly proration using the 365-day method, solve first for the daily rent amount: ($1,380 / 31), or $44.52.  Since the landlord received the rent and owes the buyer portions of the rent, the buyer will be credited.  The owed amount is for the 16th through the 31st, or 16 days, since the closing day belongs to the buyer.  Therefore, credit the buyer and debit the seller ($44.52 x 16),or $712.26

column3: A home sells for $322,600 in Primm County.  Here, transfer taxes are set at $1.00 per $500 of the sale price.  Title insurance runs $450, and the attorney costs $550.  The agent’s commission is 7%, and the mortgage balance is $210,000.  Annual real estate taxes are estimated to be $4,000, half of which will have to be charged to the seller.   If the seller pays all of these expenses, what will she net at closing?
column9: First calculate the transfer tax: ($322,600 / 500) = 645.2 units of $500.  Round this up to 646, then multiply times $1.00 to get $646 transfer tax cost.  Next figure the commission @ ($322,600 x .07), or $22,582.  Next, the seller’s real estate tax proration charge will be $2,000.   Then, add up the expenses: ($646 transfer tax + 450 title + 550 attorney + 22,582 commission + 210,000 loan payoff + 2,000 tax proration) = $236,228.  Subtracting this from the sale price = $86,372

column3: A farmer wants to net at least $5,000/acre on the sale of his 300-acre property.  If he allows for 10% commissions and closing costs, and to allow for negotiating room, he wants to get 95% of the listing price as the selling price, what should his listing price be per acre?
column9: Be careful here.  Since the net price is $5,000, the taking price (TP) minus the commission must equal the net price.  In other words, the net price is 90% of the taking price.  Since TP x 90% = Net, TP = Net / 90%. So the taking price is $5,556 ($5,000 / .9).   Apply the same logic to deriving the asking price: the taking price is 95% of the list price, therefore the list price = (taking price / 95%), or $5,848.  Now work backwards to prove your answer: (5,848 x 95% margin x .90 net of commission) = $5,000

column3: The Wildes have purchased a $740,000 home.  The land is worth 25%, and they insure the improvements @ 75% of their replacement value.  If the Wildes suffer damage estimated at $500,000, and they have an 80% co-insurance clause, what will their recovery be from the policy?
column4: Zero
column9: Use the formula: (Percent of insurable property value carried / 80% replacement cost) x claim = recovery, where the insurable property value variable excludes the land value and is valued at replacement cost.  Here, the insurable portion of the property is ($740,000 - 25% land value), or $555,000.  The Wildes are carrying insurance to cover 75% of the replacement cost of the entire property.  Their recovery amount is therefore (75% / 80%) x $500,000, or $468,750

column3: The Uptons carry a $140,000 property insurance policy which covers 75% of the replacement cost of their insurable property, valued at $190,000.  They have an 80% co-insurance requirement in the policy.  If the family incurs a $150,000 loss, what if any amount will the Uptons recover?
column9: Use the formula: (Percent of insurable property value carried / 80% replacement cost) x claim = recovery.  Thus, (75% / 80% x $150,000) = $140,625.  However, the face value of the policy is the maximum they can receive, which is $140,000

column3: A farmer temporarily installs produce coolers in a leased farm stand in order to prevent spoilage.  The coolers would be considered which of the following?
column4: Trade fixtures that are real property
column5: Trade fixtures that are personal property
column6: Temporary real property
column7: Emblements
column9: Trade fixtures are items of a tenant's  personal property that the tenant has temporarily affixed to a landlord's real property in order to conduct business.   Trade fixtures may be detached and removed before or upon surrender of the leased premises.  Should the tenant fail to remove a trade fixture, it may become the property of the landlord through accession.  Thereafter, the fixture is considered real property

column3: Property can be converted from real to personal property and from personal property to real property by means of which processes, respectively?
column4: Assemblage and plottage
column5: Application and dissolution
column6: Severance and affixing
column7: Planting and harvesting
column9: Severance is the conversion of real property to personal property by detaching it from the real estate; affixing, or attachment, is the act of converting personal property to real property by attaching it to the real estate, such as by assembling a pile of bricks into a barbecue pit, or constructing a boat dock from wood planks

column3: The highest form of ownership interest one can acquire in real estate is the
column4: legal life estate
column5: conventional life estate
column6: defeasible fee simple estate
column7: absolute fee simple estate
column9: The fee simple freehold estate is the highest form of ownership interest one can acquire in real estate.  It includes the complete bundle of rights, and the tenancy is unlimited, with certain exceptions. The fee simple absolute estate is a perpetual estate that is not conditioned by stipulated or restricted uses

column3: The distinguishing feature of a defeasible fee simple estate is that
column4: it can be passed on to heirs
column5: it has no restrictions on use
column6: the estate may revert to a grantor or heirs if the prescribed use changes
column7: it is of unlimited duration
column9: The defeasible fee estate is perpetual, provided the usage conforms to stated conditions.  Essential characteristics are: the property must be used for a certain purpose or under certain conditions; and, if the use changes or if prohibited conditions are present, the estate reverts to the previous grantor of the estate

column3: Maria acquires a property from her uncle Alfonso.  When Maria dies, the estate will pass to Alfonso's other niece, Serena.  The type of estate that Maria has in the property is a
column4: conventional life estate
column5: legal life estate
column6: fee simple defeasible estate
column7: tenancy by the entireties
column9: A conventional life estate is a freehold estate that is limited in duration to the life of the owner or other named person.  Upon the death of the owner or other named individual, the estate passes to the original owner or another named party.  A legal life estate is created by law as opposed to a property owner's choice

column3: One difference between a cooperative estate and a condominium estate is that
column4: a condominium owner owns a unit of air space whereas the co-op owner owns a proprietary lease
column5: a condominium sale adversely affects other unit owners
column6: the coop owner owns stock and a freehold real estate interest whereas the condominium owner     simply owns a proprietary lease
column7: the condominium owner owns the common elements and the airspace whereas the coop owner only owns the apartment
column9: The owner of a condominium has a fee-simple ownership interest in his/her unit and its air space. Whereas, a co-op owner has a leasehold, not fee-simple, interest with the property’s corporation. Since the corporation owns an undivided interest in the cooperative property, debts and financial obligations apply to the property as a whole, not to individual units as in a condominium

column3: Who are the essential parties involved in an estate in trust?
column4: Owner, trustor and lawyer
column5: Owner, trustor and trustee
column6: Trustee, title company, and beneficiary
column7: Trustor, trustee and beneficiary

column4: share in an association that owns one's apartment
column5: tenancy in common interest in airspace and common areas of the property

column7: fee simple ownership of a pro rata share of the entire property
column9: A condominium is a hybrid form of ownership of multi-unit residential or commercial properties.  It combines ownership of a fee simple interest in the airspace within a unit with ownership of an undivided share, as a tenant in common, of the entire property's common elements, such as lobbies, swimming pools, and hallways

column3: With various types of junior liens, the order of payment priority is generally established according to
column4: the date of recordation
column5: what form of tax is in question
column6: the order of disbursement
column7: whether the lien was subordinated
column9: Among junior liens, date of recording determines priority.  The rule is: the earlier the recording date of the lien, the higher its priority.  For example, if a judgment lien is recorded against a property on Friday, and a mortgage lien is recorded on the following Tuesday, the judgment lien has priority and must be satisfied in a foreclosure ahead of the mortgage lien

column3: What is a lien-theory state in contrast to a title-theory state?
column4: A state in which liens are given priority over other encumbrances
column5: A state in which a mortgagor retains title to the property when a mortgage lien is created
column6: A state in which the holder of a mortgage lien receives title to the mortgaged property until the debt is satisfied
column7: A state in which liens must be recorded to be enforceable
column9: In lien-theory states,  laws give a lender on a mortgaged property equitable title rather than legal title.  The mortgagor in a lien theory state retains legal title

column3: A property owner has an easement appurtenant on her property. One day the property is sold to another party who is opposed to the easement.  Following the closing, this particular form of easement
column4: terminates
column5: transfers with the property
column6: transfers with the owner to a new property
column7: becomes a license on the property
column9: The term appurtenant means "attaching to."  An easement appurtenant attaches to the estate and transfers with it unless specifically stated otherwise in the transaction documents

column3: What fundamental legal purpose is fulfilled by title records?
column4: Keeping the county apprised of tax payments
column5: Preventing identity theft
column6: Giving constructive notice of one's rights and interests in the property
column7: Assembling all relevant documents in a single place
column9: Recorded instruments may include deeds, mortgages, liens, easements, sale contracts, and marriage, probate and tax records.  The primary purpose of recording and maintaining records of these instruments is to provide constructive notice of the conditions of a property's title-- who owns it, who maintains claims against it

column3: What is "chain of title?"
column4: The list of all parties who have ever owned real estate
column5: The bundle of rights linked to the recorded title to a parcel
column6: A chronology of successive owners of record of a parcel of real estate
column7: Involuntary conveyance of title by statutory rules of descent
column9: Chain of title refers to the succession of owners of record dating back to the original grant of title from the state to a private party.  It is thus more than a mere list; it is a chronological list as reflected in title records

column3: Which of the following provides the strongest evidence of marketable title?
column4: A general warranty deed
column5: A title certificate
column6: Title insurance
column7: An attorney's opinion
column9: A title insurance policy indemnifies the policy holder against losses arising from defects in the title and is thus generally accepted as the best evidence of marketability after a Torrens certificate, which is not available in every jurisdiction. A signed deed is no evidence of marketability, only of an intent to convey title. An attorney's opinion and a title certificate, while forms of evidence of marketability, do not guarantee clear title or offer any protection against a defective title

column3: A store owner enters into a lease that charges rent per square foot, a common area fee, and a portion of the store owner's gross income from the property.  This kind of lease is a
column4: triple charge, or triple net lease
column5: proprietor's lease
column6: percentage lease
column7: retailer's gross lease
column9: A percentage lease allows the landlord to share in the income generated from the use of the property.  A tenant pays percentage rent, or an amount of rent equal to a percentage of the tenant's periodic gross sales

column3: An owner leases a property to a business in exchange for rent.  The tenant is required to pay all operating expenses as well.  This is an example of a
column4: proprietary lease
column5: percentage lease
column6: gross lease
column7: net lease
column9: A net lease requires a tenant to pay for utilities, internal repairs, and a proportionate share of taxes, insurance, and operating expenses in addition to rent

column3: A lease automatically terminates under which of the following circumstances?
column4: The tenant fails to pay rent
column5: The leased property is foreclosed
column6: The tenant goes out of business
column7: The landlord cancels the lease
column9: A foreclosure extinguishes all prior interests in a property, including a leasehold

column3: A county or municipal authority usually grants a certificate of occupancy for new construction only after
column4: all contractors’ work has been inspected
column5: all work has been completed for at least sixty days
column6: the construction conforms to building codes
column7: the tax assessor has valued the improvement
column9: Building inspectors inspect a new development or improvement for code compliance.  If the work complies, the municipality or county issues a certificate of occupancy which officially clears the property for occupation and use

column3: A property owner is precluded by deed restriction from developing a thirty foot boat dock.  The limitation prompts the owner to sell to another party.  The new owner
column4: is free to build the dock since the next door neighbor built a similar dock two weeks later
column5: takes title subject to the same restriction
column6: can build the dock with special permission from the zoning board
column7: may build, since the restriction is extinguished by the sale
column9: Deed restrictions attach to the title of the property.  Therefore, the restriction passes to the new buyer

column3: Emily sells Rycole a property containing a deed condition.  The condition stipulates that the forested portion of the property must never be razed for development.  Three months later, Rycole proceeds to harvest the trees and turn the area into an executive golf course.  What recourse, if any, does Emily have under the deed condition?
column4: She has the right to re-possess the property because the grantee has violated the condition
column5: The condition has ceased to apply because she allowed the violation to continue for a certain period of time
column6: She can claim the proceeds from the harvested trees
column7: She can force Rycole to sell the property to a new owner who agrees to comply with the condition
column9: A deed condition may restrict certain uses of a property, much like a deed restriction.  However, violation of a deed condition gives the grantor the right to re-take possession of the property and file suit for legal title

column3: What is the essential purpose of legal descriptions of real property?
column4: To create a consistent, unchanging standard for uniquely locating a property
column5: To enable courts and attorneys to calculate property size accurately
column6: To comply with common law for real property
column7: To eliminate cumbersome metes and bounds descriptions
column9: A legal description of real property is one which accurately locates and identifies the boundaries of the subject parcel to a degree acceptable by courts of law in the state where the property is located.  The general criterion for a legal description is that it alone provides sufficient data for a surveyor to locate the parcel.  A legal description identifies the property as unique and distinct from all other properties

column3: Which of the following characterizes metes and bounds descriptions?
column4: They use meridians and base lines
column5: They identify an enclosed area, beginning and ending at the same point
column6: They use lot and block numbers
column7: They incorporate elevation into the descriptions
column9: The metes and bounds description always identifies an enclosed area by starting at an origination point, called point of beginning, or POB, and returning to the POB at the end of the description

column3: A buyer agrees to all terms of a seller's offer except the length of time for a contingency to procure financing.  The buyer extends the financing period in the offer by one week, signs the form, and mails it back to the seller.  At this point, the seller's offer
column4: is void
column5: becomes an executory contract
column6: becomes a counteroffer
column7: has been accepted, since the modification was a contingency
column9: By changing any of the terms of an offer, the offeree creates a counteroffer, and the original offer is void.  At this point, the offeree becomes the offeror, and the new offeree gains the right of acceptance.  If accepted, the counteroffer becomes a valid contract provided all other requirements are met

column3: Real estate contracts that are not personal service contracts
column4: may be assigned
column5: are not assignable
column6: must be in writing
column7: are exempt from the statute of frauds
column9: A real estate contract that is not a personal contract for services can be assigned to another party unless the terms of the agreement specifically prohibit assignment.  Listing agreements, for example, are not assignable, since they are personal service agreements between agent and principal.  Sales contracts, however, are assignable, because they involve the purchase of real property rather than a personal service

column3: Which of the following contracts must be in writing to be enforceable?
column4: A parol contract
column5: A six-month lease
column6: A two-year lease
column7: An executory contract
column9: A contract may be in writing or it may be an oral, or parol, contract.  Certain oral contracts are valid and enforceable, others are not enforceable, even if valid.  For example, most states require listing agreements, sales contracts, and leases exceeding one year to be in writing to be enforceable

column3: Agent Bob, who works for Broker Bill, obtains an owner listing to lease a building.  Bill's other agent, Sue, locates a tenant for Bob's listing.  Broker Bill in this instance is
column4: an implied agent
column5: a dual agent
column6: a single agent
column7: a subagent
column9: Dual agency occurs whenever a single broker represents both principal parties to a transaction.  Here, since Bob and Sue work for Bill,  Bill is the dual agent

column3: A transaction broker should disclose his or her agency relationship to prospective buyers and sellers
column4: upon first substantive communication
column5: upon completion of the listing agreement
column6: immediately following completion of any offer
column7: Immediately prior to closing
column9: The agent must provide written notice to all parties or their agents as soon as substantive communication occurs, which can include initial face-to-face contact

column3: A transaction facilitator in a residential transaction represents
column4: the seller
column5: the buyer
column6: both seller and buyer
column7: neither seller nor buyer
column9: In recent years, the brokerage industry has striven to clear up the question of who works for whom, and who owes fiduciary duties to whom.  One solution allows a broker to represent no one in a transaction.  That is, the broker acts as a transaction broker, or facilitator, and has no allegiance to buyer or seller

column3: A principal instructs an agent to inform minority buyers that the property for lease was just leased an hour ago and is no longer available.  The agent refuses to comply.  In this case,
column4: the agent should exercise caution until the listing expires, then decline to renew it
column5: the principal has proposed an illegal act, which should not be obeyed
column6: the agent is liable for breaching the listing terms
column7: the agent may sue the principal for discrimination and misrepresentation
column9: An agent must comply with the client's directions and instructions, provided they are legal.  If the directive is illegal, the agent must also immediately withdraw

column3: The amount of a real estate broker's commission is established by
column4: agreement among competing brokers
column5: negotiation with clients
column6: the local Board of Realtors®
column7: state real estate license law
column9: The amount of a broker's commission is whatever amount the client and broker have agreed to

column3: A client revokes an exclusive right-to-sell listing two months prior to expiration.  The reason stated: the client is too busy to meet with the agent.  In this case,
column4: the client is criminally liable for negligence
column5: the client may be liable for a commission and marketing expenses
column6: the agent can sue the client for specific performance, even if no customer had been located
column7: the agent must accept the revocation without the possibility of damage recovery
column9: With an exclusive right-to-sell listing, if the property sells during the term of the revoked listing, the client is liable for the commission.  If the property does not sell, the client is liable for the broker's actual costs

column3: A protection period clause in an exclusive listing provides that
column4: the owner is protected from all liabilities arising from the agent's actions performed within the agent's scope of duties
column5: the agent has a claim to a commission if the owner sells or leases to a party within a certain time following the listing's expiration
column6: agents are entitled to extend a listing agreement's term if a transaction is imminent
column7: an owner is not liable for a commission if a prospective customer delays in completing an acceptable offer
column9: Many listings include a protection clause stating that, for a certain period after expiration, the owner is liable for the commission if the property sells to a party that the broker procured, unless the seller has since listed the property with another broker

column3: Real estate advertising must conform to regulatory standards and requirements.  One requirement is
column4: a broker may only place blind ads in social media outlets
column5: a broker must have all advertising approved by the local real estate board
column6: the advertising must not be deceptive
column7: sales agents may only advertise in their own name
column9: Advertising may not be misleading or deceptive in promoting the brokerage or listed properties.  Blind ads are also prohibited without exception.  Sales agents, moreover, must identify their employer

column3: The three principal brokerage firms in a market agree to pay sales agents 15% more than any other competitor currently in practice.  This is an example of
column4: collusion
column5: price fixing
column6: allocation of markets
column7: steering
column9: Collusion is the illegal practice of two or more businesses joining forces or making joint decisions which have the effect of putting another business at a competitive disadvantage

column3: Two leading agencies jointly agree to raise commissions charged to residential sellers to 7.5% of the sales price.  Which of the following is true?
column4: This is a perfectly legitimate business practice
column5: The brokers have illegally fixed prices
column6: The brokers have allocated markets
column7: The brokers have engaged in legal collusion
column9: Price fixing is the practice of two or more brokers agreeing to charge certain commission rates or fees for their services, regardless of market conditions or competitors

column3: A sale contract contains an open-ended financing contingency:  if the buyer cannot obtain financing within a reasonable time, the deal is off.  Six months later, the buyer still cannot secure financing.  Which of the following is true?
column4: The seller may cancel the contract, since it can be ruled invalid
column5: The buyer can continue indefinitely to seek financing, and the seller's property must remain off the market, since “reasonable” is not defined
column6: The escrow agent is entitled to the buyer's deposit
column7: The seller can force a lender to commit to a loan under fair financing laws
column9: A contingency that is too broad, vague, or excessive in duration may invalidate the entire contract on the grounds of insufficiency of mutual agreement.  To avoid problems, the statement of a contingency should be explicit and clear, have an expiration date, and expressly require diligence in the effort to fulfill the requirement

column3: In the event of a buyer's default, a provision for liquidated damages in a sale contract enables a seller to
column4: sue the buyer for specific performance
column5: force the buyer to quitclaim equitable title
column6: sue the buyer for the broker's marketing expenses
column7: claim the deposit as compensated damages for the buyer's failure to perform
column9: If a buyer fails to perform under the terms of a sale contract, the breach entitles the seller to legal recourse for damages.  The usual remedy is forfeiture of the buyer's deposit as liquidated damages, provided the deposit is not grossly in excess of the seller's actual damages

column3: Which of the following is true of an option-to-buy agreement?
column4: The potential buyer, the optionee, is obligated to buy the property once the option agreement is completed
column5: The optionor must perform if the optionee takes the option, but the optionee is under no obligation to do so
column6: The contract can be executed at no cost to the optionee
column7: It is a bilateral agreement
column9: An option-to-buy places the optionee under no obligation to purchase the property.  However, the seller must perform under the terms of the contract if the buyer exercises the option.  An option is thus a unilateral agreement.  Exercise of  the option creates a bilateral sale contract where both parties are bound to perform

column3: If a manufacturer that is the major employer in a small city moves its operations to another city, it is reasonable to expect
column4: a fall in housing demand, but no other changes in the real estate market
column5: a decline in demand for all types of real estate in the real estate market
column6: an immediate fall in the demand for industrial real estate, but no other changes in the real estate market
column7: an immediate decline in the prices for industrial and office real estate, but no impact on the residential market
column9: Businesses that support the departing company will lay off or fire new employees, causing some to leave town in search of work. Some of these businesses may also have to cease operations. Hence the demand for residential real estate, as well as for commercial and industrial, will decline, and new construction will probably also halt until some other factor increases demand again

column3: If a commercial real estate market is undersupplied, it is likely that
column4: rental prices in that market will fall
column5: rental prices in that market will rise
column6: rental prices will remain stable until equilibrium is reached
column7: construction will increase to the point of equilibrium
column9: An undersupply of commercial properties in relation to demand will most likely increase prices, as renters have fewer choices and less bargaining power

column3: The amount of available property that becomes occupied over a period of time is called
column4: vacancy
column5: absorption
column6: equilibrium
column7: occupation
column9: Absorption is the amount of available property that becomes occupied over a period of time, usually measured in square feet

column3: The roof of a property cost $20,000.  The economic life of the roof is 20 years.  Assuming the straight-line method of depreciation, what is the depreciated value of the roof after 3 years?
column9: First derive the annual depreciation, which is the cost divided by the economic life.  Then multiply annual depreciation times the number of years to identify total depreciation.  Remember to subtract depreciation from the original cost if the question asks for the ending value.  Thus, ($20,000 ÷ 20 years x 3 years) = $3,000 total depreciation.  The ending value is $20,000 – 3,000, or $17,000

column3: The income capitalization approach to appraising value is most applicable for which of the following property types?
column4: Single family homes
column5: Apartment buildings
column6: Undeveloped land
column7: Churches
column9: The income capitalization approach, or income approach, is used for income properties and sometimes for other properties in a rental market where the appraiser can find rental data.  The approach is based on the principle of anticipation: the expected future income stream of a property underlies what an investor will pay for the property

column3: In the income capitalization approach, an appraiser
column4: estimates gross income and multiplies times the gross income multiplier
column5: estimates effective income, subtracts tax, and applies a capitalization rate
column6: estimates net income and applies a capitalization rate to it
column7: estimates potential income and applies a capitalization rate to it
column9: The steps are: estimate potential gross income; estimate effective gross income (potential minus vacancy and credit losses); estimate net operating income (effective minus total operating expenses); select a capitalization rate; and apply the capitalization rate.  Use the formula: income ÷ cap rate = value

column3: Net operating income is equal to
column4: potential income minus expenses minus debt service
column5: effective gross income minus potential income
column6: potential gross income minus vacancy and credit loss minus expenses
column7: effective gross income minus vacancy and credit loss
column9: Net operating income, or NOI, is always income after vacancy, credit loss and expenses.  It does not, however, include debt service

column3: If net income on a property is $40,000 and the cap rate is 10%, the value of the property using the income capitalization method is
column9: Value = Income ÷ Cap rate.  Thus, V= $40,000 ÷ .10 =  $400,000

column3: The key feature of an adjustable mortgage loan is that
column4: the interest rate may vary
column5: the monthly payment increases over the life of the loan
column6: the principal balance does not amortize
column7: the loan term can be shortened or lengthened
column9: Adjustable rate mortgages (ARMs) allow the lender to change the interest rate at specified intervals and by a specified amount.  Federal regulations place limits on incremental interest rate increases and on the total amount by which the rate may be increased over the loan term

column3: Why is a wraparound mortgage loan potentially interesting to a home seller as an investment?
column4: It is a senior loan that can be easily subordinated for additional debt
column5: A wraparound lender can profit when the interest rate of the wraparound exceeds that of the underlying mortgage
column6: The underlying loan is retired early
column7: The second mortgage borrower may make payments directly to the first mortgage lender
column9: In a wraparound loan arrangement, the seller receives a junior mortgage from the buyer, and uses the buyer's payments to make the payments on the original first mortgage.  This potentially enables the seller to profit from any difference between a lower interest rate on the senior loan and a higher rate on the wraparound loan

column3: A builder is required to secure a loan with mortgages on three properties.  This is an example of
column4: a participation mortgage loan
column5: a blanket mortgage loan
column6: a permanent mortgage loan
column7: a bridge loan
column9: A blanket mortgage is secured by more than one property, such as multiple parcels of real estate in a development

column3: Which of the following is true of a loan with negative amortization?
column4: The interest rate on the loan increases as the principal balance decreases
column5: Payments are not sufficient to retire the loan
column6: The loan balance is diminishing, or going negative
column7: Additional interest is being added to the monthly payment
column9: Negative amortization causes the loan balance to increase over the term.  This occurs if the borrower's periodic payment is insufficient to cover the interest owed for the period.  The lender adds the amount of unpaid interest to the borrower's loan balance

column3: The loan-to-value ratio is used as an underwriting mechanism because
column4: the LTV determines the profitability of the loan
column5: the loan amount needs to be less than the property's value
column6: borrowers tend to inflate the true value of the property
column7: a full-price loan overfinances the borrower
column9: Lenders must have a margin of borrower equity to protect against falling real estate values which increase the risk of the loan.  Without this margin, a lender can incur a loan loss in a foreclosure sale since the proceeds may be less than the loan amount

column3: In the past, borrowers were often surprised by unexpected or undisclosed borrowing fees and expenses at closing.  This phenomenon has been largely corrected through disclosure requirements mandated by which of the following laws?
column4: Equal Credit Opportunity Act
column5: Truth-in-Lending laws
column6: National Disclosure Procedures Act
column7: Federal Fair Housing Laws
column9: Truth-in-Lending Laws, implemented by the Federal Reserve's Regulation Z, regulate the disclosure of costs, the right to rescind the credit transaction, advertising credit offers, and penalties for non-compliance with the act

column3: Which of the following is an important function of the secondary mortgage market?
column4: Participants borrow funds from banks so the banks can make more loans
column5: Participants issue tax certificates and sell them to primary lenders
column6: Participants purchase pools of defaulted loans from lenders to keep them solvent
column7: Participants sell mortgage-backed securities in order to buy pools of loans
column9: Secondary mortgage market organizations buy pools of mortgages from primary lenders and sell securities backed by these pooled mortgages to investors.   By selling securities, the secondary market brings investor money into the mortgage market.  By purchasing loans from primary lenders, the secondary market returns funds to the primary lenders, thereby enabling the primary lender to originate more mortgage loans

column3: Cash flow is a measure of how much pre-tax or after-tax cash an investment property generates.  To derive cash flow it is therefore necessary to exclude
column4: cost recovery expense
column5: interest expense
column6: loan principal payments
column7: net operating income
column9: Cash flow is the difference between the amount of actual cash flowing into the investment as revenue and out of the investment for expenses, debt service, and all other items.  Cash flow concerns cash items only, and therefore excludes depreciation (cost recovery), which is not a cash expense

column3: The method for deriving an investor’s return on investment, or ROI, is by
column4: dividing net operating income by cash flow
column5: multiplying the required yield times after-tax cash flow
column6: dividing net income by the price paid for the property
column7: multiplying cash flow times the price paid for the property
column9: The investment return measure known as return on investment (ROI) is calculated by dividing net income by the value of the investment.  This yields a rate of return on investment

column3: Which of the following items would affect a homeowner's  adjusted basis?
column4: Installing a higher capacity air conditioning and purifying system
column5: Replacing a washing machine
column6: Stripping and staining hardwood floors
column7: Replacing a broken picture window
column9: Basis is increased by the cost of capital improvements made to the property. Examples of capital improvements are: putting on an addition, paving a driveway, replacing a roof, adding central air conditioning, and rewiring the home. Repairs, maintenance, and redecorating are not generally considered capital improvements

column3: Which of the following is true with respect to real property taxation by the federal government?
column4: It imposes ad valorem property taxes and capital gain tax
column5: It may not impose property taxes or tax liens
column6: There are no federal ad valorem taxes on real property
column7: It imposes ad valorem tax, but not capital gain tax
column9: There are no federal taxes on real property.  The Constitution of the United States specifically prohibits such taxes.  The federal government does, however, tax income derived from real property and gains realized on the sale of real property

column3: Ad valorem taxes are based on
column4: the replacement value of property
column5: the assessed value of property
column6: the millage value of property
column7: the broker's estimate of value
column9: General property taxes are levied on an ad valorem basis, meaning that they are based on the assessed value of the property.  Assessed value is determined according to state law, usually by a county or township assessor or appraiser

column3: A retirement facility prohibits ownership of any unit by persons under 55 years of age.  The association claims it has made the prohibition properly.  Which of the following is true?
column4: They are violating the Civil Rights Act of 1866
column5: They are violating the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988
column6: They are guilty of age discrimination
column7: The prohibition may be legal if performed correctly
column9: The condominium association may be exempt from fair housing prohibitions against age discrimination if it is established as a retirement community in which 80 % of the dwellings have one person who is 55 years of age or older and it has amenities for elderly residents

column3: An agent receives a full-price offer from a minority party.  The agent presents the offer to the seller and discloses the buyer’s minority status.  The seller at that point instructs the agent to inform the buyer that the property has just gone under contract.  The agent duly complies, telling the offeror that the home has just been temporarily removed from the market and is unavailable – but may be available soon if the contract falls through.  Which party or parties, if any, have violated fair housing laws?
column4: The agent only
column5: The owner only
column6: The agent and the owner
column7: Neither agent nor owner
column9: The owner has illegally discriminated, and the agent, by going along with the owner, is equally guilty of violating fair housing laws

column3: Which of the following are examples of closing items not prorated between buyer and seller?
column4: Taxes
column5: Inspection fees
column6: Utilities
column7: Condominium assessments
column9: Prorated items are expenses that both parties must share.  Non-prorated items are one-time individual charges such as sale commissions, recording fees, and title insurance

column3: Which of the following activities is not allowed under the Real Estate Settlements and Procedures Act?
column4: A broker having any business relationship with an insurance company that is involved in the broker's transaction
column5: A broker pre-qualifying a buyer for a mortgage loan
column6: A lender requiring a deposit from a borrower for a tax and insurance escrow account
column7: A lender paying a fee to a broker for referring a borrower to the lender
column9: RESPA prohibits the payment of fees as part of a real estate settlement when no services are actually rendered.  This prohibition includes referral fees for such services as title searches, title insurance, mortgage loans, appraisals, credit reports, inspections, surveys, and legal services

column3: Which of the following communication records must (as opposed to should) be kept?
column4: Notes on every conversation
column5: Copies of required communications to principals
column6: Notes from company training sessions
column7: Business cards of licensees one meets at open houses
column9: Some communications with transaction parties are good and necessary for business. Others are required by law, and records of them must be maintained for a statutory period. Required records typically include listing agreements, offers, contracts, closing statements, agency agreements, disclosure documents, correspondence and other communication records, notes and any other relevant information

column3: To minimize the risk of violating fair housing laws, a licensee should
column4: refuse to use terms that refer to or describe any of the classes of persons protected by the laws
column5: avoid working in neighborhoods that are predominantly occupied by a single ethnic group
column6: make discriminatory or derogatory remarks in conversation only, never in writing
column7: give better service to members of a protected class than is standard for other clients or customers
column9: Before entering into a listing agreement, a licensee should explain that it is necessary to comply with fair housing laws and obtain the potential client’s acknowledgment and agreement. The agent should make it clear that the agent will  reject the use of terms indicating race, religion, creed, color, national origin, sex, handicap, age or familial status to describe prospective buyers. Such terms should be avoided in conversation as well as in advertising

column3: What are “tenant improvements?”
column4: Modifications to a rental suite to conform to a tenant’s usage specifications
column5: Marketing programs that yield a higher quality of tenant
column6: Increased revenue resulting from a rise in rental rates
column7: Increased occupancy resulting from a population increase in the market area
column9: Alterations made specifically for certain tenants are called build-outs or tenant improvements. The work may involve merely painting and re-carpeting a rental space, or erecting new walls and installing special electrical or other systems

column3: For the proper handling of client and owner monies, a property manager is generally required to
column4: deposit all funds every month in the management firm’s central operating account
column5: employ a notary to witness and record every deposit or payment received
column6: maintain a special trust account in a qualified financial depository
column7: disburse all funds to their legal owners on a weekly basis
column9: State laws and real estate commission rules specify how a property manager is to manage trust funds. In general, the agent is to maintain a separate bank account for these funds, with special accounting, in a qualified depository institution. The rules for how long an agent may hold trust funds before depositing them, and how the funds are to be disbursed, are spelled out. The fundamental requirements are that the owners of all funds must be identified, and there must be no commingling or conversion of client funds and agent funds

column3: Jennifer advised her clients they needed to paint their living room before showing the property.  The walls of these rooms were all 8’ high.  The wall lengths were 14’, 18’, 16’, and 18’.   If a gallon of paint covers 200 SF, how many whole gallons would the homesellers have to buy?
column9: The total area of the living room is (8’ x 14’ + 8’ x 18’ + 8’ x 16’ + 8’ x 18’) = 528 SF.  They will therefore need 528 / 200 SF, or 3 whole gallons

column3: An investor just purchased a rectangular 2-acre retail lot for $250 a frontage foot.  If she paid $100,000 total, what was the depth of the lot?
column9: Since the investor paid $100,000 total, and that equals $250 per frontage foot, there are 400 frontage feet (100,000 / 250).  If the property is two acres, it totals 87,120 SF.  Dividing this by 400 produces a lot depth of 217.8’

column3: Andra can afford to spend $5,000 in closing costs to refinance her home.  The lender quotes closing costs of $800 plus 2 points.  The house appraised out at $240,000, and she can get an 80% loan.  Can Annika afford to refinance?
column4: No, she is short by $64
column5: No, she is short by $1,600
column6: Yes, with $360 left over
column7: Yes, she in fact breaks even
column9: The loan she can get amounts to ($240,000 x 80%), or $192,000.  The points charge is ($192,000 x .02), or $3,840.  Total closing costs are then $3,840 + 800, or $4640.  Thus she has $360 to spare

column3: A house is being appraised using the sales comparison approach.  The house has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, and a patio.  The appraiser selects a comparable house that has three bedrooms, 2.5 bathrooms, and no patio.  The comparable house just sold for $100,000. A half-bath is valued at $5,000, and a patio at $1,000.  Assuming all else is equal, what is the adjusted value of the comparable?
column9: Since the comparable has an extra half-bath, it is adjusted downward to equalize with the subject.  Conversely, since it has no patio, the appraiser adds value to the comparable.  Thus, $100,000 minus $5,000 plus $1,000 equals $96,000

column3: A family purchased a $90,000 lot to build a custom home.  At the date of closing, the lot was assessed at $84,550 and the tax rate was $1.91 / $100 assessed valuation.   When they completed the home, the assessment increased by $235,000 to include the new construction.  If the monthly tax escrow is based on the assessed value, what will the monthly tax escrow be?
column9: The total assessed value is ($84,550 + 235,000), or $319,550.  The annual tax is based on ($319,550 / 100) = 3195.5 100's. Round up to 3196. To derive the annual tax, multiply 3,196 x 1.91, or $6,104.36.  Divide this by 12 for the monthly escrow: ($6,104 / 12) = $508

column3: The James family purchased a home for $180,000 five years ago and obtained an 80% LTV loan.  Now the property has appreciated 25%.  In addition, the loan has been paid down $11,000.  What is the James’s current equity in the home?
column9: The formula for equity is (current value – indebtedness).  The current value is ($180,000 + 25% x 180,000), or ($180,000 x 125%), or $225,000.  The current debt is ($180,000 x 80%) - $11,000, or $133,000.  Their equity is therefore $92,000

column3: George and Mary have owned a rental house for 10 years.  They bought it for $240,000 and estimated the land value @ 25%.  If the property is depreciated on a 39-year schedule, and appreciation totals 50% over the period, what is their gain if they sell the property today?
column9: Use the formula: Gain = (Net selling price – adjusted basis) where adjusted basis = (beginning cost – depreciation).  The selling price is $240,000 x 5% annual appreciation x 10 years, or ($240,000 + 50% x 240,000), or $360,000.  Since land cannot be depreciated, the depreciable basis is ($240,000 total cost – 60,000 land value), or $180,000 (land = 25% total value).  Annual depreciation = ($180,000 / 39 years), or $4,615.  Thus total depreciation is ($4,615 x 10 years), or $46,150.  The adjusted basis is therefore ($240,000 – 46,150), or $193,850.  The total gain is therefore ($360,000 – 193,850), or $166,150

column3: Adelpha’s home is valued at $250,000.  She has insurance coverage of $160,000 with an 80% co-insurance clause.  If Adelpha has a damage claim amounting to $100,000, how much will she receive from her policy?
column9: Applying the formula (percent of insurable property value carried / 80% replacement cost) x claim = recovery), divide the amount of coverage carried ($160,000) by 80% of the insurable property value ($250,000) to get the percent of the claim the company will pay (80%). Multiply this percentage by the claim amount to get $80,000, what the company will pay
